entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can use your {@classFeature Channel Divinity|Cleric||2} to inflict grievous wounds. When you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can use your Channel Divinity to add +5 to the attack's damage. If you score a critical hit with the attack, add +10 to the attack's damage instead.

subclassFeature.name: Pack Hunter
entries: Starting at 6th level, when an ally within 30 feet of you makes a weapon attack roll against a creature you attacked within this round, you can use your reaction to grant that ally advantage on the attack roll.

subclassFeature.name: Divine Strike
entries: At 8th level, you gain the ability to infuse your weapon strikes with divine energy. Once on each of your turns when you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can cause the attack to deal an extra {@damage 1d8} damage of the same type dealt by the weapon to the target. When you reach 14th level, the extra damage increases to {@damage 2d8}.

subclassFeature.name: Deadly Stalker
entries: At 17th level, you can use an action to describe or name a creature that is familiar to you or that you can see within 120 feet. For 24 hours or until the target is dead, whichever occurs first, you have advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) checks to track your target and Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks to detect your target. In addition, you have advantage on weapon attack rolls against the target. You can't use this feature again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Mercy Domain
entries: Mercy can mean promoting healing instead of harm, but it can also mean ending suffering with a quick death. These often-contradictory ideals are the two sides of mercy. The tenets of deities who embody mercy promote ways to end bloody conflicts or deliver healing magics to those in need. While mercy for some may be benevolent, for others it is decidedly not so. More pragmatic mercy gods teach the best method to relieve the agony and torment brought on by monsters and the forces of evil is to bring about the end of that evil.

entries.caption: Mercy Domain Spells
rows: 1st
{@spell divine favor}, {@spell healing word}
3rd
{@spell aid}, {@spell ray of enfeeblement}
5th
{@spell bardo|ToH}*, {@spell revivify}
7th
{@spell death ward}, {@spell sacrificial healing|ToH}*
9th
{@spell antilife shell}, {@spell raise dead}

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiencies
entries: When you choose this domain at 1st level, you take your place on the line between the two aspects of mercy: healing and killing. You gain proficiency in the {@skill Medicine} skill and with the {@item poisoner's kit|PHB}. In addition, you gain proficiency with {@filter heavy armor|items|source=|type=heavy armor} and {@filter martial weapons|items|source=|category=basic|type=martial weapon}.

subclassFeature.name: Threshold Guardian
entries: Also at 1st level, when you hit a creature that doesn't have all of its hit points with a melee weapon attack, the weapon deals extra radiant or necrotic damage (your choice) equal to half your proficiency bonus.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Involuntary Aid
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can use your {@classFeature Channel Divinity|Cleric||2} to wrest the lifeforce from an injured creature and use it to heal allies. As an action, you present your holy symbol to one creature you can see within 30 feet of you that doesn't have all of its hit points. The target must make a Wisdom saving throw, taking radiant or necrotic damage (your choice) equal to three times your cleric level on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Then, one friendly creature you can see within 30 feet of you regains a number of hit points equal to the amount of damage dealt to the target.

subclassFeature.name: Bolster the Living
entries: At 6th level, you gain the ability to manipulate a portion of the lifeforce that escapes a creature as it perishes. When a creature you can see dies within 30 feet of you, you can use your reaction to channel a portion of that energy into a friendly creature you can see within 30 feet of you. The friendly creature gains a bonus to attack and damage rolls equal to half your proficiency bonus until the end of its next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Divine Strike of Mercy
entries: At 8th level, you gain the ability to infuse your weapon strikes with the dual nature of mercy. Once on each of your turns when you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can cause the attack to deal an extra {@damage 1d6} radiant or necrotic damage (your choice) to the target. If the target dies from this attack, a friendly creature you can see within 5 feet of you regains hit points equal to half the damage dealt. If no friendly creature is within 5 feet of you, you regain the hit points instead. When you reach 14th level, the extra damage increases to {@damage 2d6}.

subclassFeature.name: Hand of Grace and Execution
entries: At 17th level, you imbue the two sides of mercy into your spellcasting. Once on each of your turns, if you cast a spell that restores hit points to one creature or deals damage to one creature, you can add your proficiency bonus to the amount of hit points restored or damage dealt.

subclassFeature.name: Portal Domain
entries: You have dedicated yourself to the study and protection of the doors, gateways, and rips in the boundaries between the physical world and the infinite planar multiverse. Stepping through portals is a sacred prayer and woe betide any who seek to misuse them.

entries.caption: Portal Domain Spells
rows: 1st
{@spell adjust position|ToH}*, {@spell expeditious retreat}
3rd
{@spell glyph of shifting|ToH}*, {@spell misty step}
5th
{@spell dimensional shove|ToH}*, {@spell portal jaunt|ToH}*
7th
{@spell dimension door}, {@spell reposition|ToH}*
9th
{@spell pierce the veil|ToH}*, {@spell  teleportation circle}

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiencies
entries: When you choose this domain at 1st level, you gain proficiency with {@filter heavy armor|items|source=|type=heavy armor} and either {@item cartographer's tools|PHB} or {@item navigator's tools|PHB} (your choice). In addition, you gain proficiency in the {@skill Arcana} skill.

subclassFeature.name: Portal Magic
entries: Starting at 1st level, you gain access to spells that connect places or manipulate the space between places. {@filter Each spell with "(liminal)" listed alongside its school|spells|subschool=liminal} is a cleric spell for you, even if it doesn't appear on the cleric spell list, and you can prepare it as you would any other spell on the cleric spell list. Liminal spells include {@spell bardo|ToH}, {@spell devouring darkness|ToH}, {@spell door of the far traveler|ToH}, {@spell ethereal stairs|ToH}, {@spell hypnagogia|ToH}, {@spell hypnic jerk|ToH}, {@spell mind maze|ToH}, {@spell mirror realm|ToH}, {@spell pierce the veil|ToH}, {@spell reciprocating portal|ToH}, {@spell rive|ToH}, {@spell subliminal aversion|ToH}, and {@spell threshold slip|ToH}. See the Magic and Spells chapter for details on these spells.

subclassFeature.name: Portal Bond
entries: At 1st level, you learn to forge a bond between yourself and another creature. At the end of a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}, you can touch one willing creature, establishing a magical bond between you. While bonded to a creature, you know the direction to the creature, though not its exact location, as long as you are both on the same plane of existence. As an action, you can teleport the bonded creature to an unoccupied space within 5 feet of you or to the nearest unoccupied space, provided the bonded creature is willing and within a number of miles of you equal to your proficiency bonus. Alternatively, you can teleport yourself to an unoccupied space within 5 feet of the bonded creature.

Once you teleport a creature in this way, you can't use this feature again until you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}. You can have only one bonded creature at a time. If you bond yourself to a new creature, the bond on the previous creature ends. Otherwise, the bond lasts until you die or dismiss it as an action

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Dimensional Shift
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can use your {@classFeature Channel Divinity|Cleric||2} to harness the magic of portals and teleportation. As an action, you teleport a willing target you can see, other than yourself, to an unoccupied space within 30 feet of you that you can see. When you reach 10th level in this class, you can teleport an unwilling target. An unwilling target that succeeds on a Wisdom saving throw is unaffected.

subclassFeature.name: Portal Touch
entries: At 6th level, you can use a bonus action to create a small portal in a space you can see within 30 feet of you. This portal lasts for 1 minute, and it doesn't occupy the space where you create it. When you cast {@filter a spell with a range of touch|spells|range=touch}, you can touch any creature within your reach or within 5 feet of the portal. While the portal is active, you can use a bonus action on each of your turns to move the portal up to 30 feet. The portal must remain within 30 feet of you. If you or the portal are ever more than 30 feet apart, the portal fades. You can have only one portal active at a time. If you create another one, the previous portal fades.You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Transpositional Divine Strike
entries: At 8th level, you gain the ability to imbue your weapon strikes with portal magic. Once on each of your turns when you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you deal damage to the target as normal, and you open a brief portal next to your target or another creature you can see within 30 feet of you. That creature takes {@damage 1d8} damage of your weapon's type as a duplicate of your weapon lashes out at the creature from the portal. When you reach 14th level, you can choose two creatures, creating a portal next to each and dealing {@damage 1d8} damage of your weapon's type to each. Alternatively, you can choose one creature and deal {@damage 2d8} damage to it.

subclassFeature.name: Portal Mastery
entries: At 17th level, when you see a creature use a magical gateway, teleport, or cast {@filter a spell that would teleport itself or another creature|spells|misctags=TP}, you can use your reaction to reroute the effect, changing the destination to be an unoccupied space of your choice that you can see within 100 feet of you. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}, unless you expend a spell slot of 5th level or higher to use this feature again.

subclassFeature.name: Serpent Domain
entries: You embody the deadly, secretive, and mesmerizing nature of serpents. Others tremble at your majesty. You practice the stealth and envenomed attacks that give serpents their dreaded reputation, but you also learn the shedding of skin that has made snakes into symbols of medicine.

entries.caption: Serpent Domain Spells
rows: 1st
{@spell charm person}, {@spell find familiar} (snakes only)
3rd
{@spell enthrall}, {@spell misty step}
5th
{@spell conjure animals} (snakes only), {@spell hypnotic pattern}
7th
{@spell freedom of movement}, {@spell polymorph} (snakes only)
9th
{@spell dominate person}, {@spell  mislead}

subclassFeature.name: Envenomed
entries: When you choose this domain at 1st level, you learn the {@spell poison spray} cantrip. In addition, you gain proficiency in the {@skill Deception} skill, with a {@item poisoner's kit|PHB}, and with {@filter martial weapons that have the Finesse property|items|source=|category=basic|type=martial weapon|property=finesse}. You can apply {@filter poison|items|source=|type=poison} to a {@filter melee weapon|items|source=|category=basic|type=melee weapon} or three pieces of ammunition as a bonus action.

subclassFeature.name: Ophidian Tongue
entries: Also at 1st level, you can communicate telepathically with serpents, snakes, and reptiles within 100 feet of you. A creature's responses, if any, are limited by its intelligence and typically convey the creature's current or most recent state, such as "hungry" or "in danger."

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Serpent Stealth
entries: Beginning at 2nd level, you can use your {@classFeature Channel Divinity|Cleric||2} to help your allies move undetected. As an action, choose up to five creatures you can see within 30 feet of you. You and each target have advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks for 10 minutes.

subclassFeature.name: Serpent's Blood
entries: Starting at 6th level, you are immune to the {@condition poisoned} condition and have resistance to poison damage.

subclassFeature.name: Divine Strike
entries: Beginning at 8th level, you can infuse your weapon strikes with venom. Once on each of your turns when you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can cause the attack to deal an extra {@damage 1d8} poison damage. Whenyou reach 14th level, the extra damage increases to {@damage 2d8}.

subclassFeature.name: Transformative Molt
entries: Beginning at 17th level, as part of a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}, you can assume a new form, your old skin crumbling to dust. You decide what your new form looks like, including height, weight, facial features, vocal tone, coloration, and distinguishing characteristics, if any. This feature works like the Change Appearance aspect of the {@spell alter self} spell, except it lasts until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.

In addition, when you are reduced to less than half your hit point maximum, you can end this transformation as a reaction to regain hit points equal to 3 times your cleric level. Once you end the transformation in this way, you can't use this feature to change your appearance again until you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Shadow Domain
entries: The shadow domain embraces the darkness that surrounds all things and manipulates the transitory gray that separates light from dark. Shadow domain clerics walk a subtle path, frequently changing allegiances and preferring to operate unseen.

entries.caption: Shadow Domain Spells
rows: 1st
{@spell bane}, {@spell false life}
3rd
{@spell blindness/deafness}, {@spell darkness}
5th
{@spell blink}, {@spell fear}
7th
{@spell evard's black tentacles}, {@spell  greater invisibility}
9th
{@spell cone of cold}, {@spell dream}

subclassFeature.name: Cover of Night
entries: When you choose this domain at 1st level, you gain proficiency in the {@skill Stealth} skill and {@sense darkvision} out to a range of 60 feet. If you already have {@sense darkvision}, its range increases by 30 feet. In addition, when you are in {@quickref Vision and Light|PHB|2|0|dim light or darkness}, you can use a bonus action to {@action Hide}.

subclassFeature.name: Lengthen Shadow
entries: Starting at 1st level, you can manipulate your own shadow to extend your reach. When you cast a {@filter cleric spell with a range of touch|spells|class=cleric|range=touch}, your shadow can deliver the spell as if you had cast the spell. Your target must be within 15 feet of you, and you must be able to see the target. You can use this feature even if you are in an area where you cast no shadow.
When you reach 10th level in this class, your shadow can affect any target you can see within 30 feet of you.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Shadow Grasp
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can use your {@classFeature Channel Divinity|Cleric||2} to turn a creature's shadow against them. As an action, choose one creature that you can see within 30 feet of you. That creature must make a Strength saving throw. If the creature fails the saving throw, it is {@condition restrained} by its shadow until the end of your next turn. If the creature succeeds, it is {@condition grappled} by its shadow until the end of your next turn. You can use this feature even if the target is in an area where it casts no shadow.

subclassFeature.name: Fade to Black
entries: At 6th level, you can conceal yourself in shadow. As a bonus action when you are in {@quickref Vision and Light|PHB|2|0|dim light or darkness}, you can magically become {@condition invisible} for 1 minute. This effect ends early if you attack or cast a spell. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Potent Spellcasting
entries: Starting at 8th level, you add your Wisdom modifier to the damage you deal with any {@filter cleric cantrip|spells|class=cleric|level=0}.

subclassFeature.name: Army of Shadow
entries: At 17th level, you can manipulate multiple shadows simultaneously. When you use {@subclassFeature Channel Divinity: Shadow Grasp|Cleric|PHB|Shadow|ToH|2} , you can affect a number of creatures equal to your proficiency bonus.

subclassFeature.name: Vermin Domain
entries: You exemplify the cunning, stealth, and invasiveness of vermin (rodents, scorpions, spiders, ants, and other insects). As your dedication to this domain grows in strength, you realize a simple truth: vermin are everywhere, and you are legion.

entries.caption: Vermin Domain Spells
rows: 1st
{@spell detect poison and disease} (vermin only), {@spell speak with animals}
3rd
{@spell spider climb}, {@spell web}
5th
{@spell conjure animals} (vermin only), {@spell fear}
7th
{@spell dominate beast}  (vermin only), {@spell  giant insect}
9th
{@spell contagion}, {@spell insect plague}

subclassFeature.name: The Unseen
entries: When you choose this domain at 1st level, you gain proficiency with {@item shortsword|PHB|shortswords} and {@item hand crossbow|PHB|hand crossbows}. You also gain proficiency in {@skill Stealth} and {@skill Survival}. You can communicate simple ideas telepathically with vermin, such as mice, spiders, and ants, within 100 feet of you. A vermin's responses, if any, are limitedby its intelligence and typically convey the creature's current or most recent state, such as "hungry" or "in danger."

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Swarm Step
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can use your {@classFeature Channel Divinity|Cleric||2} to evade attackers. As a bonus action, or as reaction when you are attacked, you transform into a swarm of vermin and move up to 30 feet to an unoccupied space that you can see. This movement doesn't provoke {@action opportunity attack|PHB|opportunity attacks}. When you arrive at your destination, you rever to your normal form.

subclassFeature.name: Legion of Bites
entries: At 6th level, you can send hundreds of spectral vermin to assail an enemy and aid your allies. As an action, choose a creature you can see within 30 feet of you. That creature must succeed on a Constitution saving throw against your spell save DC or be covered in spectral vermin for 1 minute. Each time one of your allies hits the target with a weapon attack, the target takes an extra {@damage 1d4} poison damage. A creature that is immune to {@condition disease} is immune to this feature.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Divine Strike
entries: At 8th level, you gain the ability to infuse your weapon strikes with divine energy. Once on each of your turns when you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can cause the attack to deal an extra {@damage 1d8} poison damage to the target. When you reach 14th level, the extra damage increases to {@damage 2d8}.

subclassFeature.name: Verminform Blessing
entries: At 17th level, you become a natural lycanthrope. You use the statistics of a {@creature wererat|MM}, though your form can take on insectoid aspects, such as mandibles, compound eyes, or antennae, instead of rat aspects; whichever aspects are most appropriate for your deity. Your alignment doesn't change as a result of this lycanthropy, and you can't spread the disease of lycanthropy.

subclassFeature.name: Wind Domain
entries: You have dedicated yourself to the service of the primordial winds. In their service, you are the gentle zephyr brushing away adversity or the vengeful storm scouring the stones from the mountainside.

entries.caption: Wind Domain Spells
rows: 1st
{@spell feather fall}, {@spell thunderwave}
3rd
{@spell gust of wind}, {@spell misty step}
5th
{@spell fly}, {@spell wind wall}
7th
{@spell conjure minor elementals}  (air only), {@spell  freedom of movement}
9th
{@spell cloudkill}, {@spell conjure elemental} (air only)

subclassFeature.name: Wind's Chosen
entries: When you choose this domain at 1st level, you learn the {@spell mage hand} cantrip and gain proficiency in the {@skill Nature} skill. When you cast {@spell mage hand}, you can make the hand invisible, and you can control the hand as a bonus action.

subclassFeature.name: Channel Divinity: Grasp Not the Wind
entries: At 2nd level, you can use your {@classFeature Channel Divinity|Cleric||2} to end the {@condition grappled} condition on yourself and gain a {@quickref Flying Movement|PHB|3|0|flying speed} equal to your walking speed until the end of your turn. You don't provoke {@action opportunity attack|PHB|opportunity attacks} while flying in this way.

subclassFeature.name: Stormshield
entries: At 6th level, when you take lightning or thunder damage, you can use your reaction to gain resistance to lightning and thunder damage, including against the triggering attack, until the start of your next turn. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Divine Strike
entries: At 8th level, you infuse your weapon strikes with divine energy. Once on each of your turns when you hit a creature with a weapon attack, you can cause the attack to deal an extra {@damage 1d8} thunder damage to the target. When you reach 14th level, the extra damage increases to {@damage 2d8}.

subclassFeature.name: Dire Tempest
entries: At 17th level, you can create a 20-foot-radius tornado of swirling wind and debris at a point you can see within 120 feet. The storm lasts until the start of your next turn. All Huge or smaller creatures within the area must make a Strength saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failure, a creature takes {@damage 8d6} bludgeoning damage and is thrown {@damage 1d410} feet into the air. On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn't thrown into the air. Creatures thrown into the air take {@quickref Falling|XGE|2|0|falling damage} damage as normal and land {@condition prone}.

In addition, each creature that starts its turn within 15 feet of the tornado must succeed on a Strength saving throw against your spell save DC or be dragged into the tornado's area. A creature that enters the tornado's area is thrown {@damage 1d410} feet into the air, taking {@quickref Falling|XGE|2|0|falling damage} as normal and landing {@condition prone}.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of Ash
entries: Druids of the Circle of Ash believe in the power of rebirth and resurrection, both physical and spiritual. The ash they take as their namesake is the result of burning and death, but it can fertilize the soil and help bring forth new life. For these druids, ash is the ultimate symbol of the elegant cycle of life and death that is the foundation of the natural world. Some such druids even use fresh ash to clean themselves, and the residue is often kept visible on their faces.

Druids of this circle often use the phoenix as their symbol, an elemental creature that dies and is reborn from its own ashes. These druids aspire to the same purity and believe resurrection is possible if they are faithful to their beliefs. Others of this circle are drawn to volcanos and find volcanic eruptions and their resulting ash clouds to be auspicious events.
All Circle of Ash druids request to be cremated after death, and their ashes are often given over to others of their order. What later happens with these ashes, none outside the circle know.

subclassFeature.name: Ash Cloud
entries: At 2nd level, you can expend one use of your {@classFeature Wild Shape|Druid||2} and, rather than assuming a beast form, create a small, brief volcanic eruption beneath the ground, causing it to spew out an ash cloud. As an action, choose a point within 30 feet of you that you can see. Each creature within 5 feet of that point must make a Dexterity saving throw against your spell save DC, taking {@damage 2d8} bludgeoning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

This eruption creates a 20-foot-radius sphere of ash centered on the eruption point. The cloud spreads around corners, and its area is {@quickref Vision and Light|PHB|2|0|heavily obscured}. When a creature enters the cloud for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, that creature must succeed on a Constitution saving throw against your spell save DC or have disadvantage on ability checks and saving throws until the start of its next turn. Creatures that don't need to breathe or that are immune to poison automatically succeed on this saving throw.
You automatically succeed on this saving throw while within the area of your ash cloud, but you don't automatically succeed if you are in another Circle of Ash druid's ash cloud.
The cloud lasts for 1 minute, until you use a bonus action to dismiss it, or until a wind of moderate or greater speed (at least 10 miles per hour) disperses it.

subclassFeature.name: Firesight
entries: Starting at 2nd level, your vision can't be obscured by ash, fire, smoke, fog, or the cloud created by your Ash Cloud feature, but it can still be obscured by other effects, such as {@quickref Vision and Light|PHB|2|0|dim light}, dense foliage, or rain. In addition, you have advantage on saving throws against gas or cloud-based effects, such as from the {@spell cloudkill} or {@spell stinking cloud} spells, a gorgon's petrifying breath, or a kraken's ink cloud.

subclassFeature.name: Covered in Ash
entries: At 6th level, when a creature within 30 feet of you that you can see (including yourself) takes damage, you can use your reaction to cover the creature in magical ash, giving it {@quickref temporary hit points|PHB|3|0} to twice your proficiency bonus. The target gains the {@quickref temporary hit points|PHB|3|0} before it takes the damage. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

In addition, while your {@subclassFeature Ash Cloud|Druid|PHB|Ash|ToH|2} feature is active and you are within 30 feet of it, you can use a bonus action to teleport to an unoccupied space you can see within the cloud. You can use this teleportation no more than once per minute.

subclassFeature.name: Feed the Earth
entries: At 10th level, your {@subclassFeature Ash Cloud|Druid|PHB|Ash|ToH|2} feature becomes more potent. Instead of the normal eruption effect, when you first create the ash cloud, each creature within 10 feet of the point you chose must make a Dexterity saving throw against your spell save DC, taking {@damage 2d8} bludgeoning damage and {@damage 2d8} fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

In addition, when a creature enters this more potent ash cloud for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, that creature has disadvantage on ability checks and saving throws while it remains within the cloud. Creatures are affected even if they hold their breath or don't need to breathe, but creatures that are immune to poison are immune to this effect.

If at least one creature takes damage from the ash cloud's eruption, you can use your reaction to siphon that destructive energy into the rapid growth of vegetation. The area within the cloud becomes {@quickref difficult terrain|PHB|4|0} that lasts while the cloud remains. You can't cause this growth in an area that can't accommodate natural plant growth, such as the deck of a ship or inside a building.
The ash cloud now lasts for 10 minutes, until you use a bonus action to dismiss it, or until a wind of moderate or greater speed (at least 10 miles per hour) disperses it.

subclassFeature.name: From the Ashes
entries: Beginning at 14th level, when you are reduced to 0 hit points, your body is consumed in a fiery explosion. Each creature of your choice within 30 feet of you must make a Dexterity saving throw against your spell save DC, taking {@damage 6d6} fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. After the explosion, your body becomes a pile of ashes.

At the end of your next turn, you reform from the ashes with all of your equipment and half your maximum hit points. You can choose whether or not you reform {@condition prone}. If your ashes are moved before you reform, you reform in the space that contains the largest pile of your ashes or in the nearest unoccupied space. After you reform, you suffer one level of {@condition exhaustion}.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of Bees
entries: Druids of the Circle of Bees are friends to all stinging insects but focus their attention on honeybees and other pollinating insects. When not adventuring, they tend hives, either created by the insects or by themselves. They tap into the horror inherent in stinging insects to protect their allies or the fields hosting their bee friends.

subclassFeature.name: Circle Spells
entries: Your bond with bees and other stinging beasts grants you knowledge of certain spells. At 2nd level, you learn the {@spell true strike} cantrip. At 3rd, 5th, 7th, and 9th levels, you gain access to the spells listed for those levels in the Circle of Bees Spells table.

Once you gain access to a circle spell, you always have it prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day. If you gain access to a spell that doesn't appear on the druid spell list, the spell is nonetheless a druid spell for you.

entries.caption: Circle of Bees Spells
rows: 3rd
{@spell blur}, {@spell bombardment of stings|ToH}*
5th
{@spell fly}, {@spell haste}
7th
{@spell giant insect}, {@spell locate creature}
9th
{@spell insect plague}, {@spell rary's telepathic bond}

subclassFeature.name: Bee Bond
entries: When you choose this circle at 2nd level, you gain proficiency in the {@skill Acrobatics} or {@skill Stealth} skill (your choice), and you can speak and understand Bee Dance, a language shared by bees that involves flying in dance-like patterns. Bees refuse to attack you, even with magical coercion.

When a beast other than a bee attacks you with a weapon that deals poison damage, such as a giant spider's bite or a  scorpion's sting, it must succeed on a Charisma saving throw against your spell save DC or have disadvantage on its attack rolls against you until the start of its next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Bee Stinger
entries: Also at 2nd level, you can use an action and expend one use of your {@classFeature Wild Shape|Druid||2} to grow a bee's stinger, typically growing from your wrist, which you can use to make unarmed strikes. When you hit with an unarmed strike while this stinger is active, you use Wisdom instead of Strength for the attack, and your unarmed strike deals piercing damage equal to {@damage 1d4} + your Wisdom modifier + poison damage equal to half your proficiency bonus, instead of the bludgeoning damage normal for an unarmed strike.The stinger lasts for a number of hours equal to half your druid level (rounded down) or until you use your {@classFeature Wild Shape|Druid||2} again.

When you reach 6th level in this class, your unarmed strikes count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage, and the poison damage dealt by your stinger equals your proficiency bonus. In addition, the unarmed strike damage you deal while the stringer is active increases to {@damage 1d6} at 6th level, {@damage 1d8} at 10th level, and {@damage 1d10} at 14th level.

subclassFeature.name: Bumblebee Rush
entries: At 6th level, you can take the {@action Dash} action as a bonus action. When you do so, creatures have disadvantage on attack rolls against you until the start of your next turn. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Hive Mind
entries: At 10th level, when you cast {@spell rary's telepathic bond}, each creature in the link has advantage on Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma checks if at least one creature in the link has proficiency in a skill that applies to that check. In addition, if one creature in the link succeeds on a Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check to notice a hidden creature or on a Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check, each creature in the link also succeeds on the check. Finally, when a linked creature makes an attack, it has advantage on the attack roll if another linked creature that can see it uses a reaction to assist it.

subclassFeature.name: Mantle of Bees
entries: At 14th level, you can use an action to cover yourself in bees for 1 hour or until you dismiss them (no action required). While you are covered in a mantle of bees, you gain a +2 bonus to AC, and you have advantage on Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) checks. In addition, when a creature within 5 feet of you hits you with a melee weapon, it must make a Constitution saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failure, the attacker takes {@damage 1d8} piercing damage and {@damage 1d8} poison damage and is {@condition poisoned} until the end of its next turn. On a successful save, the attacker takes half the damage and isn't {@condition poisoned}.

While the mantle is active, you can use an action to direct the bees to swarm a 10-foot-radius sphere within 60 feet of you. Each creature in the area must make a Constitution saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failure, a creature takes {@damage 4d6} piercing damage and {@damage 4d6} poison damage and is {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. On a success, a creature takes half the damage and isn't {@condition poisoned}. The bees then disperse, and your mantle ends.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}, unless you expend a spell slot of 5th level or higher to create the mantle again.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of Crystals
entries: Circle of Crystals druids first arose in subterranean environments, where they helped tend giant crystal gardens, but now they can be found most anywhere with access to underground caverns or geothermal activity. These druids view crystals as a naturally occurring form of order and perfection, and they value the crystals' slow growth cycle, as it reminds them the natural world moves gradually but eternally. This teaches young druids patience and assures elder druids their legacy will be carried on in each spire of crystal. As druids of this circle tend their crystals, they learn how to use the harmonic frequencies of different crystals to create a variety of effects, including storing magic.

subclassFeature.name: Resonant Crystal
entries: When you choose this circle at 2nd level, you learn to create a special crystal that can take on different harmonic frequencies and properties. It is a Tiny object and can serve as a spellcasting focus for your druid spells. As a bonus action, you can cause the crystal to shed {@quickref Vision and Light|PHB|2|0|bright light} in a 10-foot radius and {@quickref Vision and Light|PHB|2|0|dim light} for an additional 10 feet. You can end the light as a bonus action.

Whenever you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}, you can attune your crystal to one of the following harmonic frequencies. The crystal can have only one harmonic frequency at a time, and you gain the listed benefit while you are wearing or carrying the crystal. The crystal retains the chosen frequency until you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

entries.name: Clarity
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition frightened} or {@condition charmed}.

entries.name: Cleansing
entries: You have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition poisoned}, and you have resistance to poison damage.

entries.name: Focus
entries: You have advantage on Constitution saving throws that you make to maintain {@condition concentration} on a spell when you take damage.

entries.name: Healing
entries: When you cast a {@filter spell of 1st level or higher that restores hit points|spells|level=1;2;3;4;5;6;7;8;9|misctags=HL} to a creature, the creature regains additional hit points equal to your proficiency bonus.

entries.name: Vitality
entries: Whenever you cast a {@filter spell of 1st level or higher|spells|level=1;2;3;4;5;6;7;8;9} using the resonant crystal as your focus, one creature of your choice that you can see within 30 feet of you gains {@quickref temporary hit points|PHB|3|0} to twice your proficiency bonus. The {@quickref temporary hit points|PHB|3|0} last for 1 minute.

To create or replace a lost resonant crystal, you must perform a 1-hour ceremony. This ceremony can be performed during a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}, and it destroys the previous crystal, if one existed. If a previous crystal had a harmonic frequency, the new crystal has that frequency, unless you create the new crystal during a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Crystalline Skin
entries: Starting at 6th level, when you take damage, you can use a reaction to cause your skin to become crystalline until the end of your next turn. While your skin is crystalline, you have resistance to cold damage, radiant damage and bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from nonmagical attacks, including to the triggering damage if it is of the appropriate type. You choose the exact color and appearance of the crystalline skin.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Magical Resonance
entries: At 10th level, you can draw on stored magical energy in your {@subclassFeature Resonant Crystal|Druid|PHB|Crystals|ToH|2} to restore some of your spent magic. While wearing or carrying the crystal, you can use a bonus action to recover one expended spell slot of 3rd level or lower. If you do so, you can't benefit from the {@subclassFeature Resonant Crystal|Druid|PHB|Crystals|ToH|2}'s harmonic frequency for 1 minute.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Crystalline Form
entries: At 14th level, as a bonus action while wearing or carrying your {@subclassFeature Resonant Crystal|Druid|PHB|Crystals|ToH|2}, you can expend one use of your {@classFeature Wild Shape|Druid||2} feature to assume a crystalline form instead of transforming into a beast. You gain the following benefits while in this form:

items: You have resistance to cold damage, radiant damage, and bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from nonmagical attacks.
You have advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

Your {@subclassFeature Resonant Crystal|Druid|PHB|Crystals|ToH|2} pulses with power, providing you with the benefits of all five harmonic frequencies. When you cast a {@filter spell of 1st level or higher|spells|level=1;2;3;4;5;6;7;8;9}, you can choose to activate only the Healing or Vitality harmonic frequencies or both. If you activate both, you can choose two different targets or the same target.

entries: This feature lasts 1 minute, or until you dismiss it as a bonus action.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of Sand
entries: The Circle of Sand originally arose among the desert dunes, where druids forged an intimate connection with the sands that surrounded them. Now such circles gather anywhere with excess sand, including coastlines or badlands.

While the unacquainted might view sand as lifeless and desolate, druids of this circle know the truth—there is life within the sand, as there is almost anywhere. These druids have witnessed the destructive power of sand and the sandstorm and know to fear and respect them. Underestimating the power of sand is only for the foolish.

subclassFeature.name: Sand Form
entries: When you join this circle at 2nd level, you learn to adopt a sandy form. You can use a bonus action to expend one use of your {@classFeature Wild Shape|Druid||2} feature and transform yourself into a form made of animated sand rather than transforming into a beast form. While in your sand form, you retain your game statistics. Because your body is mostly sand, you can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing, and you have advantage on ability checks and saving throws to escape a {@action grapple} or the {@condition restrained} condition.

You choose whether your equipment falls to the ground in your space, merges into your new form, or is worn by it. Worn equipment functions as normal, but the GM decides whether it is practical for the equipment to move with you if you flow through particularly narrow spaces.

You can stay in your sand form for 10 minutes, or until you dismiss it (no action required), are incapacitated, die, or use this feature again. While in your sand form, you can use a bonus action to do one of the following:

entries.name: Abrasive Blast
entries: You launch a blast of abrasive sand at a creature you can see within 30 feet of you. Make a ranged spell attack. On a hit, the creature takes slashing damage equal to {@damage 1d8} + your Wisdom modifier.

entries.name: Stinging Cloud
entries: You emit a cloud of fine sand at a creature you can see within 5 feet of you. The target must succeed on a Constitution saving throw against your spell save DC or be {@condition blinded} until the end of its next turn.

When you reach 10th level in this class, you can stay in your sand form for 1 hour or until you dismiss it as a bonus action. In addition, the damage of Abrasive Blast increases to {@damage 2d8}, and the range of Stinging Cloud increases to 10 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Diffuse Form
entries: Also at 2nd level, when you are hit by a weapon attack while in your {@subclassFeature Sand Form|Druid|PHB|Sand|ToH|2}, you can use your reaction to gain resistance to nonmagical bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage until the start of your next turn. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Sand Dervish
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can use a bonus action to create a sand dervish in an unoccupied space you can see within range. The sand dervish is a cylinof whirling sand that is 10 feet tall and 5 feet wide. A creature that ends its turn within 5 feet of the sand dervish must make a Strength saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, the creature takes {@damage 1d8} slashing damage and is pushed 10 feet away from the dervish. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage and isn't pushed.

As a bonus action on your turn, you can move the sand dervish up to 30 feet in any direction. If you ram the dervish into a creature, that creature must make the saving throw against the dervish's damage, and the dervish stops moving this turn. When you move the dervish, you can direct it over barriers up to 5 feet tall and float it across pits up to 10 feet wide.The sand dervish lasts for 1 minute or until you dismiss it as a bonus action. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.
When you reach 10th level in this class, the damage dealt by the dervish increases to {@damage 2d8}.

subclassFeature.name: Echo of the Dunes
entries: At 10th level, your connection with sand deepens, and you can call on the power of the deep dunes to do one of the following:

entries.name: Sand Sphere
entries: You can use an action to conjure a 20-foot radius sphere of thick, swirling sand at a point you can see within 90 feet. The sphere spreads around corners, and its area is {@quickref Vision and Light|PHB|2|0|heavily obscured}. A creature moving through the area must spend 3 feet of movement for every 1 foot it moves. The sphere lasts for 1 minute or until you dismiss it (no action required).

entries.name: Whirlwind
entries: You can use an action to transform into a whirlwind of sand until the start of your next turn. While in this form, your movement speed is doubled, and your movement doesn't provoke {@action opportunity attack|PHB|opportunity attacks}. While in whirlwind form, you have resistance to all damage, and you can't be {@condition grappled}, {@condition petrified}, knocked {@condition prone}, {@condition restrained}, or {@condition stunned}, but you also can't cast spells, can't make attacks, and can't manipulate objects that require fine dexterity.
Once you use one of these options, you can't use this feature again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Sandstorm
entries: At 14th level, you can use an action to create a sandstorm of swirling wind and stinging sand. The storm rages in a cylinder that is 10 feet tall with a 30-foot radius centered on a point you can see within 120 feet. The storm spreads around corners, its area is {@quickref Vision and Light|PHB|2|0|heavily obscured}, and exposed flames in the area are doused. The buffeting winds and sand make the area {@quickref difficult terrain|PHB|4|0}. The storm lasts for 1 minute or until you dismiss it as a bonus action.

When a creature enters the area for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there, that creature must make a Strength saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, it takes {@damage 2d8} slashing damage and is knocked {@condition prone}. On a successful save, it takes half as much damage and isn't knocked {@condition prone}.
You are immune to the effects of the storm, and you can extend that immunity to a number of creatures that you can see within 120 feet of you equal to your proficiency bonus.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of the Green
entries: Druids of the Circle of the Green devote themselves to the plants and green things of the world, recognizing the role of plants in giving life. By continued communion with plant life, they believe they draw nearer to what they call "The Green," a cosmic thread that binds all plant life. Druids of this circle believe they gain their abilities by tapping into the Green, and they use this connection to summon a spirit from it.

subclassFeature.name: Circle Spells
entries: When you join this circle at 2nd level, you form a bond with a plant spirit, a creature of the Green. Your link with this spirit grants you access to some spells when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown on the Circle of the Green Spells table.

Once you gain access to one of these spells, you always have it prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day. If you gain access to a spell that doesn't appear on the druid spell list, the spell is nonetheless a druid spell for you.

entries.caption: Circle of the Green Spells
rows: 2nd
{@spell entangle}, {@spell goodberry}
3rd
{@spell barkskin}, {@spell spike growth}
5th
{@spell speak with plants}, {@spell vine carpet|ToH}*
7th
{@spell dreamwine|Toh}*, {@spell hallucinatory terrain}
9th
{@spell enchanted bloom|ToH}*, {@spell tree stride}

subclassFeature.name: Summon Green Spirit
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can summon a spirit of the Green, a manifestation of primordial plant life. As an action, you can expend one use of your {@classFeature Wild Shape|Druid||2} feature to summon the {@creature green spirit|ToH} rather than assuming a beast form.

The spirit appears in an unoccupied space of your choice that you can see within 30 feet of you. When the spirit appears, the area in a 10-foot radius around it becomes tangled with vines and other plant growth, becoming  {@quickref difficult terrain|PHB|4|0} until the start of your next turn.

The spirit is friendly to you and your companions and obeys your commands. See this creature's game statistics in the {@creature green spirit|ToH} stat block, which uses your proficiency bonus (PB) in several places.You determine the spirit's appearance. Some spirits take the form of a humanoid figure made of gnarled branches and leaves, while others look like creatures with leafy bodies and heads made of gourds or fruit. Some even resemble beasts, only made entirely of plant material.

In combat, the spirit shares your initiative count, but it takes its turn immediately after yours. The {@creature green spirit|ToH} can move and use its reaction on its own, but, if you don't issue any commands to it, the only action it takes is the Dodge action. You can use your bonus action to direct it to take the {@action Attack}, {@action Dash}, {@action Disengage}, {@action Help}, {@action Hide}, or {@action Search} action or an action listed in its statistics. If you are incapacitated, the spirit can take any action of its choice, not just {@action Dodge}.

The spirit remains for 1 hour, until it is reduced to 0 hit points, until you use this feature to summon the spirit again, or until you die. When it manifests, the spirit bears 10 fruit that are infused with magic. Each fruit works like a berry created by the {@spell goodberry} spell.

subclassFeature.name: Gift of the Green
entries: At 6th level, the bond with your {@subclassFeature Summon Green Spirit|Druid|PHB|Green|ToH|2||green spirit} enhances your restorative spells and gives you the power to cast additional spells. Once before the spirit's duration ends, you can cast one of the following spells without expending a spell slot or material components: {@spell locate animals or plants}, {@spell pass without trace} (only in environments with ample plant life), {@spell plant growth}, or {@spell speak with plants}. You can't cast a spell this way again until the next time you summon your green spirit.
Whenever you cast a {@filter spell that restores hit points|spells|misctags=HL} while your green spirit is summoned, roll a {@damage d8} and add the result to the total hit points restored.
In addition, when you cast a {@filter spell with a range other than self|spells|range=!self}, the spell can originate from you or your {@creature green spirit|ToH}.

subclassFeature.name: Verdant Interference
entries: Starting at 10th level, when a creature you can see within 30 feet of you or your {@subclassFeature Summon Green Spirit|Druid|PHB|Green|ToH|2||green spirit} is attacked, you can use your reaction to cause vines and vegetation to burst from the ground and grasp at the attacker, giving the attacker disadvantage on attack rolls until the start of your next turn.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Spirit Symbiosis
entries: At 14th level, while your {@subclassFeature Summon Green Spirit|Druid|PHB|Green|ToH|2||green spirit} is within 30 feet of you, you can use an action to join with it, letting its plant matter grow around you. While so joined, you gain the following benefits:

items: You gain {@quickref temporary hit points|PHB|3|0} to your {@creature green spirit|ToH}'s current hit points.
You gain a climbing speed of 30 feet.
You have advantage on Constitution saving throws.
The ground within 10 feet of you is {@quickref difficult terrain|PHB|4|0|Difficult terrain} for creatures hostile to you.

You can use a bonus action on each of your turns to make a tendril attack against one creature within 10 feet of you that you can see. Make a melee spell attack. On a hit, the target takes bludgeoning damage equal to {@damage 2d8} + your Wisdom modifier.

entries: This feature lasts until the {@quickref temporary hit points|PHB|3|0} you gained from this feature are reduced to 0, until the spirit's duration ends, or until you use an action to separate. If you separate, the {@creature green spirit|ToH} has as many hit points as you had {@quickref temporary hit points|PHB|3|0} remaining. If this effect ends because your {@quickref temporary hit points|PHB|3|0} are reduced to 0, the {@creature green spirit|ToH} disappears until you summon it again.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of the Shapeless
entries: Druids of the Circle of the Shapeless believe that oozes, puddings, and jellies serve an important and integral role in the natural world, particularly in decomposition and in clearing detritus. Druids of this circle also admire the adaptability of these gelatinous creatures and study them to learn how to duplicate some of their abilities.
The sworn enemies of Circle of the Shapeless druids are the so-called ooze lords and their servants who pervert the natural order by controlling and weaponizing such creatures.

subclassFeature.name: Circle Spells
entries: When you join this circle at 2nd level, your connection with oozes grants you access to certain spells. At 2nd level, you learn the {@spell acid splash} cantrip. At 3rd, 5th, 7th, and 9th level you gain access to the spells listed for that level in the Circle of the Shapeless Spells table. Once you gain access to one of these spells, you always have it prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day. If you gain access to a spell that doesn't appear on the druid spell list, the spell is nonetheless a druid spell for you.

entries.caption: Circle of the Shapeless Spells
rows: 3rd
{@spell enlarge/reduce}, {@spell spider climb}
5th
{@spell iron gut|ToH}*, {@spell meld into stone}
7th
{@spell blight}, {@spell freedom of movement}
9th
{@spell contagion}, {@spell seeming}

subclassFeature.name: Ooze Form
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you learn to adopt an ooze form. You can use a bonus action to expend one use of your {@classFeature Wild Shape|Druid||2} feature to take on an ooze-like form rather than transforming into a beast.

While in your ooze form, you retain your game statistics, but your body becomes less substantial and appears wet and slimy. Your skin may change in color and appearance, resembling other forms of ooze like black pudding, ochre jelly, gray ooze, or even translucent, like a gelatinous cube.

You choose whether your equipment falls to the ground in your space, merges into your new form, or is worn by it. Worn equipment functions as normal, but the GM decides whether it is practical for the equipment to move with you if you flow through particularly narrow spaces.
Your ooze form lasts for 10 minutes or until you dismiss it (no action required), are incapacitated, die, or use this feature again.
While in ooze form, you gain the following benefits:

entries.name: Acid Weapons
entries: Your melee weapon attacks deal an extra {@damage 1d6} acid damage on a hit.

entries.name: Amorphous
entries: You can move through a space as narrow as 1 inch wide without squeezing.

entries.name: Climber
entries: You have a climbing speed of 20 feet.

entries.name: Oozing Form
entries: When a creature touches you or hits you with a melee attack while within 5 feet of you, you can use your reaction to deal {@damage 1d6} acid damage to that creature.

subclassFeature.name: Slimy Pseudopod
entries: At 6th level, you can use a bonus action to cause an oozing pseudopod to erupt from your body for 1 minute or until you dismiss it as a bonus action. On the turn you activate this feature, and as a bonus action on each of your subsequent turns, you can make a melee spell attack with the pseudopod against a creature within 5 feet of you. On a hit, the target takes {@damage 1d6} acid damage.

You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}. When you reach 10th level in this class, the acid damage dealt by your pseudopod increases to {@damage 2d6}.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Ooze Form
entries: At 10th level, your {@subclassFeature Ooze Form|Druid|PHB|Shapeless|ToH|2} becomes more powerful. It now lasts 1 hour, and the acid damage dealt by your Acid Weapons and Oozing Form increases to {@damage 2d6}.

subclassFeature.name: Engulfing Embrace
entries: At 14th level, while in your {@subclassFeature Ooze Form|Druid|PHB|Shapeless|ToH|2}, you can use an action to move into the space of a creature within 5 feet of you that is your size or smaller and try to engulf it. The target creature must make a Dexterity saving throw against your spell save DC.

On a successful save, the creature can choose to be pushed 5 feet away from you or to an unoccupied space within 5 feet of you. A creature that chooses not to be pushed suffers the consequences of a failed saving throw.

On a failed save, you enter the creature's space, and the creature takes {@damage 2d6} acid damage and is engulfed. The engulfed creature is {@condition restrained} and has {@quickref Cover|PHB|3|0|total cover} against attacks and other effects outside of your body. The engulfed creature takes {@damage 4d6} acid damage at the start of each of your subsequent turns. When you move, the engulfed creature moves with you.

An engulfed creature can attempt to escape by taking an action to make a Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check against your spell save DC. On a success, the creature escapes and enters a space of its choice within 5 feet of you.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}, unless you expend a spell slot of 5th level or higher to try to engulf another creature.

subclassFeature.name: Circle of the Wind
entries: Founded in deserts, badlands, and grasslands, where wind dominates and controls the landscape, the teachings of the Circle of Wind have spread far and wide, like a mighty storm. Druids who follow this circle's teachings embrace the mercurial winds to create several effects.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Cantrip
entries: At 2nd level when you choose this circle, you learn the {@spell message} cantrip.

subclassFeature.name: Circle Spells
entries: The magic of the wind flows through you, granting access to certain spells. At 3rd, 5th, 7th, and 9th level, you gain access to the spells listed for that level in the Circle of Wind Spells table.

Once you gain access to one of these spells, you always have it prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day. If you gain access to a spell that doesn't appear on the druid spell list, the spell is nonetheless a druid spell for you.

entries.caption: Circle of the Wind Spells
rows: 3rd
{@spell blur}, {@spell gust of wind}
5th
{@spell fly}, {@spell lightning bolt}
7th
{@spell conjure minor elementals}, {@spell freedom of movement}
9th
{@spell cloudkill}, {@spell conjure elemental} (air elemental only)

subclassFeature.name: Feathered Form
entries: Starting at 2nd level, when you use your {@classFeature Wild Shape|Druid||2} to magically assume the shape of a beast, it can have a {@filter flying speed|bestiary|challenge rating=[&0;&1]|type=beast} (you ignore "no flying speed" in the Limitations column of the Beast Shapes table but must abide by the other limitations there).

subclassFeature.name: Comforting Breezes
entries: Beginning at 6th level, as an action, you can summon a gentle breeze that extends in a 30-foot cone from you. Choose a number of targets in the area equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of 1). You end one {@condition disease} or the {@condition blinded}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition paralyzed}, or {@condition poisoned} condition on each target. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Updraft
entries: Also at 6th level, you can expend one use of {@classFeature Wild Shape|Druid||2} as a bonus action to summon a powerful wind. You and each creature of your choice within 10 feet of you end the {@condition grappled} or {@condition restrained} conditions. You can fly up to 30 feet as part of this bonus action, and each creature that you affect with this wind can use a reaction to fly up to 30 feet. This movement doesn't provoke {@action opportunity attack|PHB|opportunity attacks}.

subclassFeature.name: Vizier of the Winds
entries: Starting at 10th level, you can ask the winds one question, and they whisper secrets back to you. You can cast {@spell commune} without preparing the spell or expending a spell slot. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Hunger of Storm's Fury
entries: Beginning at 14th level, when you succeed on a saving throw against a spell or effect that deals lightning damage, you take no damage and instead regain a number of hit points equal to the lightning damage dealt. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Buccaneer
entries: Honing their martial skills in fierce ship-to-ship combat, buccaneers become skilled in both gun and blade, able to lay out opponents with savage shots, while resisting the worst that can be thrown at them.

subclassFeature.name: Black Powder and Sailcloth
entries: At 3rd level, you gain proficiency with {@item gunsmith's tools|ToH} and with {@filter water vehicles|items|source=|type=vehicle}. You also have advantage on Strength ({@skill Athletics}) checks made to climb or swim.

subclassFeature.name: Bullet and Blade
entries: At 3rd level, when you engage in {@quickref two-weapon fighting|PHB|3} with a {@filter light melee weapon|items|source=|category=basic|type=melee weapon|property=light} that you're holding in one hand, you can use a {@item pistol|ToH} in your other hand in place of a {@filter light melee weapon|items|source=|category=basic|type=melee weapon|property=light} to make the bonus action attack. While fighting in this fashion, being within 5 feet of a hostile creature doesn't impose disadvantage on your ranged attack rolls with the {@item pistol|ToH}. If your {@quickref two-weapon fighting|PHB|3} bonus action attack is made with a {@item pistol|ToH}, you can add your Dexterity modifier to the damage of that attack.

subclassFeature.name: Gun Mastery
entries: When you choose this archetype at 3rd level, you gain access to special maneuvers that can be enacted when the damage from your firearm attack causes a gunpowder burst (see the {@variantrule Gunpowder Burst|ToH|gunpowder weapon property} in the Adventuring Gear chapter). In addition, the number of times you can roll {@variantrule Gunpowder Burst|ToH|burst damage} on a single attack is 1 + your proficiency bonus.

entries.name: Burst Maneuvers
entries: You learn two burst maneuvers of your choice, which are detailed below. You can apply a burst maneuver as a reaction when you gain a {@variantrule Gunpowder Burst|ToH|burst} on the damage roll of a weapon with the gunpowder property. The maneuver's effect is in addition to the extra damage dice from a {@variantrule Gunpowder Burst|ToH|burst}. You can apply only one burst maneuver to any given attack, regardless of the number of {@variantrule Gunpowder Burst|ToH|bursts} it has. If the maneuver calls for a saving throw, the DC equals:
You can use this reaction a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.
You learn one additional burst maneuver of your choice at 7th, 10th, and 15th level. Each time you learn new burst maneuvers, you can also replace one maneuver you know with a different one.

entries.name: Deafening Blast
entries: A creature within 5 feet of you when you fired the shot must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or be {@condition deafened} for 1 minute. This creature doesn't need to be the target of the attack that caused the {@variantrule gunpowder burst|ToH}.

entries.name: Hobble
entries: Your weapon's {@variantrule Gunpowder Burst|ToH|burst} damaged the target's leg, wing, or other ambulatory limb. The target must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or its speed is reduced by 10 feet until it receives magical healing or finishes a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}. This effect is cumulative, but it can't reduce a target's speed to less than 5 feet.

entries.name: Penetrating Shot
entries: If your target is Large or smaller, the {@variantrule Gunpowder Burst|ToH|burst} causes the shot to go through your target. If another creature is within 10 feet of the target, and a direct line can be drawn from the creature to you with the original target in between, then the new creature must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or take damage as if hit by a normal attack from the weapon. This damage can't {@variantrule Gunpowder Burst|ToH|burst}.

entries.name: Powerful Shot
entries: The target must succeed on a Strength saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone} by the {@variantrule Gunpowder Burst|ToH|burst}.

entries.name: Pummel
entries: The power of the {@variantrule Gunpowder Burst|ToH|burst} empowers you to strike a nearby creature. You can make one melee weapon attack with a {@filter melee weapon|items|source=|category=basic|type=melee weapon} you are wielding against a creature within your melee weapon's range.

entries.name: Smoke Cloud
entries: The shot produces a large amount of smoke, {@quickref Vision and Light|PHB|2|0|heavily obscuring} your space until the start of your next turn.

entries.name: Soft Spot
entries: Your weapon's {@variantrule Gunpowder Burst|ToH|burst} causes the target an extreme amount of pain. The target must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or be {@condition incapacitated} until the start of your next turn.

entries.name: Sudden Advance
entries: The {@variantrule Gunpowder Burst|ToH|burst} energizes you, causing you to leap into action. You can immediately move up to half your speed. This movement doesn't provoke {@action opportunity attack|PHB|opportunity attacks}.

entries.name: Unsteadying Shot
entries: The {@variantrule Gunpowder Burst|ToH|burst} destabilized the target. The target must succeed on a Strength saving throw or have disadvantage on all attacks until the start of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Deck Fighter
entries: At 7th level, your training keeps you nimble, allowing you to maintain balance and reflexive responses at the worst of times. When you fail a Dexterity saving throw, you can choose to succeed instead. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Seasoned Seadog
entries: At 10th level, the damage you deal with gunpowder weapons can {@variantrule Gunpowder Burst|ToH|burst} when a damage die results in either of the two highest numbers on the die (such as a 5 or 6 on a d6 or a 7 or 8 on a d8), instead of only the highest number on the die.

subclassFeature.name: Unrelenting Spirit
entries: Beginning at 15th level, if you are suffering from one of the following conditions at the start of your turn, you can end the condition as a bonus action: {@condition blinded}, {@condition charmed}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition frightened}, {@condition incapacitated}, {@condition paralyzed}, or {@condition stunned}. Alternatively, you can use a bonus action to reduce your {@condition exhaustion} level by 1. You can't use this feature again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Vicious Marauder
entries: At 18th level, you become a master of fighting with {@subclassFeature Bullet and Blade|Fighter|PHB|Buccaneer|ToH|3} in the thick of combat. When you make a ranged attack with a {@item pistol|ToH} at a creature you can see within 5 feet of you, you have advantage on the attack roll if you already hit that creature with a melee weapon attack this turn. If you score a critical hit with this attack, you can apply up to two {@subclassFeature Burst Maneuvers|Fighter|PHB|Buccaneer|ToH|3} to the attack, provided the damage had at least one {@variantrule Gunpowder Burst|ToH|burst}.

subclassFeature.name: Chaplain
entries: Militaries and mercenary companies often contain members of various clergies among their ranks. These chaplains typically come from religious sects whose tenets promote war, healing, peace, protection, or freedom, and they tend to the emotional and physical well-being of their charges. In the eyes of your companions, you are as much a counselor and spiritual leader as you are a fellow warrior.

subclassFeature.name: Student of Faith
entries: When you choose this archetype at 3rd level, you gain proficiency in the {@skill Insight}, {@skill Medicine}, or {@skill Religion} skill (your choice).

subclassFeature.name: Field Medic
entries: Beginning at 3rd level, you can use an action to spend one of your Hit Dice and regain hit points. The hit points regained with this feature can be applied to yourself or to another creature you touch. Alternatively, you can heal another creature you touch when you spend Hit Dice to regain hit points during a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|short rest}, instead of applying the regained hit points to yourself. If you are under an effect that increases the amount of healing you receive when spending Hit Dice, such as a spell or feat, that effect applies to the amount of hit points the target regains. Keep in mind, some effects that increase the healing of Hit Dice happen only when those Hit Dice are spent during a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|short rest}, like a bard's {@classFeature Song of Rest (D6)|Bard||2}.

In addition, the number of Hit Dice you regain after a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest} is equal to half your total number of Hit Dice plus one. For example, if you have four Hit Dice, you regain three spent Hit Dice, instead of two, when you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Rally the Troops
entries: Starting at 7th level, you can use an action to urge your companions to overcome emotional and spiritual obstacles. Each friendly creature of your choice that can see or hear you (which can include yourself) ignores the effects of being {@condition charmed} and {@condition frightened} for 1 minute.

If a creature affected by this feature is already suffering from one of the conditions it can ignore, that condition is suppressed for the duration and resumes when this feature ends. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.

Each target can ignore additional conditions when you reach certain levels in this class: one level of {@condition exhaustion} and incapacitated at 10th level, up to two levels of {@condition exhaustion} and {@condition stunned} at 15th level, and up to three levels of {@condition exhaustion} and {@condition paralyzed} at 17th level.

subclassFeature.name: Tend the Injured
entries: At 10th level, if you spend Hit Dice to recover hit points during a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|short rest}, any hit points regained that exceed your hit point maximum, or that of the creature being tended to, can be applied to another creature within 5 feet of you. In addition, you regain one spent Hit Die when you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Rally Point
entries: Beginning at 15th level, when a friendly creature you can see takes damage, you can use your reaction to move that creature up to its speed toward you. The creature can choose the path traveled, but it must end the movement closer to you than it started. This movement doesn't provoke {@action opportunity attack|PHB|opportunity attacks}. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Hospitaler
entries: At 18th level, you recover a number of spent Hit Dice equal to a quarter of your total Hit Dice when you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short rest}. In addition, you recover all your spent Hit Dice when you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Legionary
entries: A legionary follows the techniques of close-quarters combat developed by soldiers fighting shoulder to shoulder with their allies. This style of fighting spread far and wide, finding an honored place among the armies and mercenary companies of other races. True legionaries scoff at the image of the storybook hero standing alone against impossible odds, knowing together they can face any danger and emerge victorious.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiency
entries: When you choose this archetype at 3rd level, you gain proficiency in the {@skill Insight}, {@skill Nature}, or {@skill Survival} skill (your choice).

subclassFeature.name: Coordinated Fighting
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you learn techniques and strategies for close-quarter combat. On your first attack each round, you gain a +1 bonus to the attack and damage rolls if at least one friendly creature is within 5 feet of you.

subclassFeature.name: Move As One
entries: At 3rd level, at any point while moving on your turn, you can command a number of willing, friendly creatures within 5 feet of you up to your proficiency bonus to move with you. Each creature that chooses to move with you can use a reaction to move up to its speed alongside you, remaining within 5 feet of you while moving. This movement doesn't provoke {@action opportunity attack|PHB|opportunity attacks}. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses of it when you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Massed Fighting
entries: Starting at 7th level, you learn better techniques and strategies for fighting closely alongside your allies. On your first attack each round, you gain a +1 bonus to the attack and damage rolls for each friendly creature within 5 feet of you, up to a maximum bonus equal to your proficiency bonus.

In addition, when you use your {@classFeature Action Surge|Fighter||2} feature, each friendly creature within 15 feet of you (except you) gains a +2 bonus to AC and to Dexterity saving throws for 1 minute.

subclassFeature.name: Tactical Positioning
entries: At 15th level, moving through a hostile creature's space is not {@quickref difficult terrain|PHB|4|0} for you, and you can move through a hostile creature's space even if it is only one size larger or smaller than you. As normal, you can't end your move in a hostile creature's space.

subclassFeature.name: Cooperative Strike
entries: Starting at 18th level, when you use the {@action Attack} action and attack with a weapon while at least one friendly creature is within 5 feet of you, you can use a bonus action to make one additional attack with that weapon.

subclassFeature.name: Pugilist
entries: Pugilists live by their fists, bare-knuckle warriors who do not hesitate to throw hands if the situation demands it. They know the intense, close, violent intimacy of melee, and they operate unapologetically in that space. Whether in fighting pits by the docks to make some extra coin, in the king's grand arena as champions of quarreling nobles, or in the employ of local merchants in need of seemingly weaponless guards, pugilists can be found in all rungs of society. Pugilists take pleasure in a battle hard won and thrill in the energy of the fight rather than in a kill. They can often be found celebrating or having drinks with a former opponent hours after the fight, regardless of the bout's winner.

subclassFeature.name: Unarmed Warrior
entries: When you choose this archetype at 3rd level, you learn to use your fists, knees, elbows, head, and feet to attack your opponents. You gain the following benefits while you are not wearing {@filter heavy armor|items|source=|category=basic|type=heavy armor} and while you are not wielding weapons or a {@item shield|PHB}:

items: Your unarmed strikes deal bludgeoning damage equal to {@damage 1d6} + your Strength modifier on a hit. Your unarmed strike damage increases as you reach higher levels. The {@damage d6} becomes a {@damage d8} at 10th level and a {@damage d10} at 18th level.
When you use the {@action Attack} action to make one or more unarmed strikes, you can make one unarmed strike as a bonus action.

entries.name: Pugilists and Magical Unarmed Strikes
entries: Unlike monks and their ki, pugilist fighters don't naturally have a means of making unarmed strikes count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage. Some magic items, such as the {@item cestus|ToH} (see the Magic Items chapter) or the swolbold wraps (see Vault of Magic), specifically make unarmed strikes magical, but not every campaign includes magic weapons or magic items.

As a GM, if you are running a game in a high-magic setting and would like to give a pugilist player character the opportunity for their unarmed strikes to count as magical, we recommend allowing the pugilist to utilize the magic in their magic items. The pugilist must be attuned to the item, and the item must be worn on the hands, arms, or feet, such as gloves, a ring, bracers, or boots. The amount of magical bonus the pugilist receives depends on the rarity of the item. An {@filter uncommon magic item|items|source=|rarity=uncommon} allows the pugilist's unarmed strikes to count as magical, a {@filter rare magic item|items|source=|rarity=rare} gives the pugilist a +1 bonus to attack and damage rolls, and {@filter very rare|items|source=|rarity=very rare} and {@filter legendary magic items|items|source=|rarity=legendary} give +2 and +3 bonuses, respectively.

subclassFeature.name: Resilient Fighter
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you learn to endure great amounts of physical punishment. You add your Constitution modifier (minimum of 1) to any death saving throw you make. In addition, you can use {@classFeature Second Wind|Fighter||1} a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Uncanny Fortitude
entries: Beginning at 7th level, if damage reduces you to 0 hit points, you can make a Constitution saving throw with a DC: of 5 + the damage taken, unless the damage is from a critical hit. On a success, you drop to 1 hit point instead. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.
