You are proficient with the attack, it counts as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage, and you add your Dexterity modifier to the attack and damage rolls. The damage is of a type appropriate to the object, such as piercing for a thorny branch or bludgeoning for a rock, and the damage die is a {@damage d8}.

subclassFeature.name: Living Bulwark
entries: Starting at 15th level, the land around you comes to your aid when you are in danger, interposing rocks, branches, vines, roots, or even the ground itself between you and your foes. When a creature you can see targets you with an attack, you can use your reaction to roll a {@damage d8} and add it to your AC against the attack.

subclassFeature.name: Gunslinger
entries: Gunslingers use their expertise to hunt and track for coin, using their marksmanship skills to bring down their prey. Some gunslingers work by a personal code that defines what they will or will not do for money, while others have no scruples in who or what they hunt.

subclassFeature.name: Gunslinger Magic
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you learn an additional spell when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown in the Gunslinger Spells table. The spell counts as a ranger spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of ranger spells you know.

entries.caption: Gunslinger Spells
rows: 3rd
{@spell hunter's mark}
5th
{@spell hold person}
9th
{@spell clairvoyance}
13th
{@spell locate creature}
17th
{@spell legend lore}

subclassFeature.name: Trick Shot
entries: You can use your {@filter firearms|items|source=|type=firearm} to pull off special feats of marksmanship. Trick shots provide special effects or secondary functions to your {@filter firearm|items|source=|type=firearm} attacks. Unless otherwise stated, you can use a trick shot as part of the same action you use to attack with the {@filter firearm|items|source=|type=firearm}. You can use only one trick shot each turn. If you are wielding a {@item blunderbuss|ToH}, you can use only the Deafening Blast and Haft Strike trick shots.
If a trick shot requires a saving throw against its effects, the DC equals:
Some trick shots reference weapon options, which can be found in the Adventuring Rules chapter of this book.

entries.name: Deafening Blast
entries: As your bullet flies toward your target, you can cause one creature you can see within 5 feet of the path of the shot to make a Constitution saving throw. On a failure, the creature is {@condition deafened} for 1 minute. The creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success.

entries.name: Disarming Shot
entries: You can use the {@action Disarm|DMG} weapon option when attacking with a firearm. If the target is beyond the normal range for the weapon, it has advantage on its saving throw. Use your trick shot DC for this saving throw instead of the weapon option DC.

entries.name: Haft Strike
entries: As a bonus action after you load your firearm, you can whip the weapon around and use the stock to make a melee attack at a target within 5 feet of you. This attack deals {@damage 1d6} bludgeoning damage if done with a {@filter one-handed firearm|items|source=|type=firearm|property=!two-handed}, or {@damage 1d8} bludgeoning damage with a {@filter two-handed firearm|items|source=|type=firearm|property=two-handed}, plus your Strength modifier.

entries.name: Improved Ricochet Shot
entries: You can use the {@action Ricochet Shot|ToH} weapon option against a target that has {@quickref Cover|PHB|3|0|total cover}, provided you are aware of which space the target occupies.

entries.name: Manipulate Object
entries: You can fire a round from your gun to manipulate an object at a distance, up to the maximum range of your firearm. This allows you to take the {@action Use an Object} action from a distance, though your action is limited to things that can be done with the impact of the bullet, such as punching a button, moving a lever, severing a rope, or similar actions.

You can also use this trick shot to move an object weighing no more than 10 pounds, pushing it up to 5 feet away from its original location. If an object is being worn or carried, the creature wearing or carrying it must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw to prevent the object from being moved.

entries.name: Shifting Shot
entries: You fire a shot into a space occupied by a Large or smaller creature, near its feet or body. The creature must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or be compelled to move 5 feet in a direction of your choosing. The creature automatically succeeds on this saving throw if it would be compelled to move into damaging terrain, such as lava or a pit.

subclassFeature.name: Defensive Tactics
entries: At 7th level, you gain one of the following features of your choice.

entries.name: Die Hard
entries: When you fail a death saving throw, you can choose to succeed instead. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

entries.name: Fortified Hearing
entries: You are immune to the {@condition deafened} condition.

entries.name: Return Fire
entries: When a hostile creature you can see makes a ranged attack against you before your turn (including during the first round of combat), you can make a ranged attack against that enemy as a reaction.

entries.name: Sudden Withdrawal
entries: When a creature you can see hits you with a melee attack, you can move up to half your speed as a reaction after the damage is dealt. This movement doesn't provoke {@action opportunity attack|PHB|opportunity attacks}.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Trick Shot
entries: At 11th level, your impressive marksmanship allows you to perform even greater trick shots with more powerful effects. These improved trick shots require more focus, and you must use an action to perform an improved trick shot.

entries.name: Disruptive Shot
entries: Make one ranged attack with your firearm. On a hit, if the target is {@condition concentration|PHB|concentrating} on a spell, the DC of the Constitution saving throw to maintain {@condition concentration} is equal to 10 or the full damage taken, whichever is higher.

entries.name: Sharpshooter
entries: Make one ranged attack with your firearm. Attacking at long range doesn't impose disadvantage on this attack roll. On a hit, double your damage dice for the attack. If you are firing a {@item blunderbuss|ToH}, choose one target in range to take the extra damage, rolling normally for the rest.

entries.name: Stunning Shot
entries: Make one ranged attack with your firearm. On a hit, the target takes damage as normal and must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or be {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Deadeye
entries: Beginning at 15th level, your weapon attacks with {@filter firearms|items|source=|type=firearm} score a critical hit on a roll of 19 or 20.

subclassFeature.name: Haunted Warden
entries: Haunted Wardens use their expertise to hunt and track for coin, using their marksmanship skills to bring down their prey. Some gunslingers work by a personal code that defines what they will or will not do for money, while others have no scruples in who or what they hunt.

subclassFeature.name: Beyond the Pale
entries: Starting when you choose this archetype at 3rd level, you can use a bonus action to see into the Ethereal Plane for 1 minute. Ethereal creatures and objects appear ghostly and translucent.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Haunted Warden Magic
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you learn an additional spell when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown in the Haunted Warden Spells table. The spell counts as a ranger spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of ranger spells you know.

entries.caption: Haunted Warden Spells
rows: 3rd
{@spell false life}
5th
{@spell invisibility}
9th
{@spell speak with dead}
13th
{@spell death ward}
17th
{@spell dispel evil and good}

subclassFeature.name: Spirit Usher
entries: At 3rd level, you gain an undead spirit that anchors itself to you and accompanies you on your journeys. The spirit is friendly to you and your companions and obeys your commands. See the spirit's game statistics in the {@creature Spirit Usher|ToH} stat block, which uses your proficiency bonus (PB) in several places.

You determine the spirit's appearance, name, and personality. You should choose a personality trait, ideal, bond, and flaw for it, and you should work with your GM to decide on a background story for the spirit that fits the campaign.

In combat, the spirit shares your initiative count, but it takes its turn immediately after yours. It can move and use its reaction on its own, but, if you don't issue any commands to it, the only action it takes is the {@action Dodge} action. You can use your bonus action to direct it to take the {@action Attack}, {@action Dash}, {@action Disengage}, {@action Help}, {@action Hide}, or {@action Search} action or an action listed in its statistics. If you are {@condition incapacitated}, the spirit can take any action of its choice, not just {@action Dodge}.

When it joins with you, the spirit learns three cantrips it can cast at will, which you select from the following lists. At the end of a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}, you can change which cantrips the spirit knows.

items: Choose one of {@spell chill touch}, {@spell ray of frost}, {@spell sacred flame}, or {@spell vicious mockery}. Use your level when determining the damage of the chosen cantrip.
Choose one of {@spell druidcraft}, {@spell prestidigitation}, or {@spell thaumaturgy}.
Choose one of {@spell dancing lights}, {@spell message}, or {@spell minor illusion}.

entries: The spirit is bonded to you. It can't be turned or destroyed, such as with the cleric's {@classFeature Channel Divinity: Turn Undead|Cleric||2||Turn Undead} feature. When the {@creature spirit usher|ToH} dies, it retreats to the Ethereal Plane to restore itself and returns to an unoccupied space within 5 feet of you when you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}. If the {@creature spirit usher|ToH} died within the last hour, you can use your action to expend a spell slot of 1st level or higher to return it to life after 1 minute with all its hit points restored.

subclassFeature.name: Merge Spirit
entries: Starting at 7th level, you can use an action to cause your {@subclassFeature Spirit Usher|Ranger|PHB|Haunted Warden|ToH|3} to join its essence with you for 1 minute. While merged, you gain the {@creature spirit usher|ToH}'s Ethereal Sight trait and can interact with creatures and objects on both the Ethereal and Material Planes. In addition, while you are merged, you become less substantial and gain the {@creature spirit usher|ToH}'s damage resistances and damage immunities.
Once you use this feature, you shouldn't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|short or long rest}. Each time you use it again, you suffer one level of {@condition exhaustion}.

subclassFeature.name: Guardian Geist
entries: At 11th level, when you take damage that would reduce you to 0 hit points, you can use your reaction to call out to your {@subclassFeature Spirit Usher|Ranger|PHB|Haunted Warden|ToH|3}. If you do, your {@creature spirit usher|ToH} teleports to an unoccupied space within 5 feet of you and takes half the damage dealt to you, potentially preventing your death.
In addition, when your  {@creature spirit usher|ToH} dies, you have advantage on attack rolls until the end of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: True Psychopomp
entries: At 15th level, you can use your {@subclassFeature Merge Spirit|Ranger|PHB|Haunted Warden|ToH|7} feature as a bonus action instead of an action. When you and your  {@creature spirit usher|ToH} merge forms, you gain its ncorporeal Movement trait and Etherealness action, and you are considered to be undead for the purposes of determining whether or not spells or other magical effects can affect you.

subclassFeature.name: Snake Speaker
entries: Like the serpents they adore, snake speakers are highly adaptable hunters. Snakes are common throughout the world, and people who need to travel through snake-filled jungles often retain a snake speaker guide, trusting the guide to protect them from scaly poisoners.

subclassFeature.name: Snake Speaker Magic
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you learn an additional spell when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown in the Snake Speaker Spells table. The spell counts as a ranger spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of ranger spells you know.

entries.caption: Snake Speaker Spells
rows: 3rd
{@spell charm person}
5th
{@spell suggestion}
9th
{@spell tongues}
13th
{@spell confusion}
17th
{@spell dominate person}

subclassFeature.name: Scaly Transition
entries: Beginning at 3rd level, you can take on limited serpentine aspects. When you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}, select one of the following features. You gain the benefit of the chosen feature until the next time you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}. Starting at 11th level, you can select two options when you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

entries.name: Bite
entries: You develop venomous fangs. When you use the {@action Attack} action and attack with a weapon, you can use a bonus action to bite a target within 5 feet of you with your fangs. You are proficient with the fangs, which deal piercing damage equal to {@damage 1d4} + your Strength or Dexterity modifier (your choice) plus {@damage 1d8} poison damage on a hit.

entries.name: Keen Smell
entries: Your nose and olfactory organs change to resemble those belonging to a snake. You have advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on scent and on Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) checks.

entries.name: Poison Resistance
entries: You have resistance to poison damage.

entries.name: Scales
entries: Scales sprout along your body. When you aren't wearing armor, your AC equals 13 + your Dexterity modifier.

entries.name: Serpentine Movement
entries: You have a {@quickref Climbing, Swimming, and Crawling|PHB|4|0|climbing speed} of 30 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Speak with Snakes
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you can comprehend and verbally communicate with snakes. A snake's knowledge and awareness are limited by its Intelligence, but it can give you information about things it has perceived within the last day. You can persuade a snake to perform small favors for you, such as carrying a written message to a nearby companion.

subclassFeature.name: Serpent Shape
entries: When you reach 7th level, you can use an action to cast {@spell polymorph} on yourself, assuming the shape of a {@creature giant constrictor snake}, {@creature flying snake}, or {@creature giant poisonous snake}. While you are in the form of a snake, you retain your Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma scores. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

Starting at 15th level, you retain the benefits of your {@subclassFeature Scaly Transition|Ranger|PHB|Snake Speaker|ToH|3} feature while in the form of a snake, and you can use this feature twice between rests.

subclassFeature.name: Sinuous Dance
entries: Beginning at 11th level, your physical movements can beguile your enemies and strengthen your magic. You can choose to use Dexterity as your spellcasting ability score instead of Wisdom.

In addition, when you cast a spell, you can add your Dexterity and Wisdom modifiers together and use the result as your spellcasting ability modifier when determining the DC or spell attack bonus for that spell. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Decoy Skin
entries: Starting at 15th level, you learn to magically shed your skin and use it as an animate decoy. As an action, you can shed your skin, which creates a duplicate of yourself. The duplicate appears in an unoccupied space within 10 feet of you. It looks like you, has your Armor Class and saving throw bonuses, and has hit points equal to three times your ranger level. It lasts for 10 minutes or until it is reduced to 0 hit points.

As a bonus action, you can command it to move up to your speed, using any form of movement you possess, but it must remain within 120 feet of you. Your decoy can't take actions or use your class features, but it otherwise moves as directed. While your decoy is within 5 feet of you, its appearance and movements so closely mimic yours that when a creature that can reach you and your decoy makes an attack against you, it has a 50 percent change of hitting your decoy instead.

It looks exactly as you looked when you used this feature, and it is a convincing duplicate of you. A creature can discern that it isn't you with a successful Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check against your spell save DC. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Spear of the Weald
entries: The alseid have long defended the limits of their forest homes. These warriors can make a dizzying variety of ranged and melee attacks in quick succession, using ancient magic to flash across the battlefield.

entries.subclassFeature: Touch of the Fey Land|Ranger|PHB|Spear of the Weald|ToH|3

subclassFeature.name: Restriction: Alseid
entries: You can choose this archetype only if you are an {@race alseid|ToH}.

subclassFeature.name: Weald Spear
entries: When you choose this archetype at 3rd level, you gain the ability to call forth a magical, wooden spear from the land of fey into your empty hand as a bonus action. The spear disappears if it is more than 5 feet away from you for 1 minute or more. It also disappears if you use this feature again, if you dismiss the weapon (no action required), or if you die. You are proficient with the weapon while you wield it. The spear's range is 20/60 feet, and, when you throw the spear, it reappears in your hand after the attack. The spear's damage die is a {@damage d8}, and it has the finesse and reach properties.

At 7th level, your weald spear attack counts as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage, and your weald spear's damage die is a {@damage d10}. At 11th level, your weald spear's damage die is a {@damage d12}.

subclassFeature.name: Touch of the Fey Land
entries: The touch of the land of the fey is always on your spear, hinting at its otherworldly ties. Beginning at 3rd level, when you summon your {@subclassFeature Weald Spear|Ranger|PHB|Spear of the Weald|ToH|3}, choose one of the following effects.

entries.name: Aflame
entries: Your spear is ensorcelled in heatless, white, magical flames whose intensity rise and fall to reflect your mood. When you are at your happiest, your spear sheds {@quickref Vision and Light|PHB|2|0|bright light} in a 5-foot radius and {@quickref Vision and Light|PHB|2|0|dim light} for an additional 5 feet.

entries.name: Entwined
entries: Your spear appears to be wrapped in writhing green vines which occasionally coalesce into the shape of a slender, grasping hand. The hand always points in the direction of your home forest.

entries.name: Everblooming
entries: Your spear is covered in small wildflowers that bloom, die, bud, and bloom again within minutes. Pollinating insects are often drawn to your spear as the spear constantly exudes a pleasant, floral fragrance.

entries.name: Moonlit
entries: Your spear appears as a pale length of wooden moonlight. A trail of star-like motes travels behind the spear's point.

subclassFeature.name: Canopy
entries: Beginning at 7th level, when a creature within 30 feet of you, including yourself, is targeted by a ranged weapon attack, you can use your reaction to summon a magical canopy of glowing leaves and branches over the target. The target has resistance to the damage dealt by the attack, and the canopy bursts into shredded leaves afterwards. You must then finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest} to use your Canopy again.

When you reach 11th level in this class, you can use your Canopy twice between {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0| rests}, and at 18th level, you can use it three times between {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0| rests}. When you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}, you regain all expended uses.

subclassFeature.name: Steps of the Forest God
entries: Starting at 11th level, after you make a successful ranged weapon attack with your {@subclassFeature Weald Spear|Ranger|PHB|Spear of the Weald|ToH|3}, you can use a bonus action to teleport to an unoccupied space within 10 feet of your target.

subclassFeature.name: Overwhelm
entries: At 15th level, after you make a successful melee weapon attack with your {@subclassFeature Weald Spear|Ranger|PHB|Spear of the Weald|ToH|3} against a creature, you can use a bonus action to make one ranged weapon attack with it against a different creature. You don't have disadvantage on the ranged attack roll from being within 5 feet of the first creature you hit, however, you can still have disadvantage on the attack roll from being within 5 feet of other creatures.

subclassFeature.name: Wasteland Strider
entries: A barren landscape wracked by chaotic magics, crawling with strange monstrosities and twisted aberrations that warp the minds of those who lay eyes upon them ... you have learned to traverse these wastes and face these creatures without flinching. You patrol its boundaries and stride unseen through its harsh landscape, evading danger and protecting those who find themselves at the mercy of the arcana-laced wilds and eldritch horrors.

subclassFeature.name: Chaotic Strikes
entries: When you choose this archetype at 3rd level, you've learned to channel the unpredictable energies of magical wastelands into your weapon attacks. You can use a bonus action to imbue your weapon with chaotic energy for 1 minute. Roll a {@damage d8} and consult the Chaotic Strikes table to determine which type of energy is imbued in your weapon. While your weapon is imbued with chaotic energy, it deals an extra {@damage 1d4} damage of the imbued type to any target you hit with it. If you are no longer holding or carrying the weapon, or if you fall {@condition unconscious}, this effect ends.

entries.caption: Chaotic Strikes
rows: Fire
Cold
Lightning
Psychic
Necrotic
Poison
Radiant
Force

subclassFeature.name: Wasteland Strider Magic
entries: Also tarting at 3rd level, you learn an additional spell when you reach certain levels in this class, as shown in the Wasteland Strider Spells table. The spell counts as a ranger spell for you, but it doesn't count against the number of ranger spells you know.

entries.caption: Wasteland Strider Spells
rows: 3rd
{@spell protection from the void|ToH}*
5th
{@spell calm emotions}
9th
{@spell dispel magic}
13th
{@spell banishment}
17th
{@spell hold monster}

subclassFeature.name: Stalwart Psyche
entries: Starting at 7th level, you have learned to guard your mind against the terrors of the unknown and to pierce the illusions of the otherworldly creatures that lurk in the wastelands. You have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened} and on ability checks and saving throws to discern illusions.

subclassFeature.name: Call the Otherworldly
entries: At 11th level, you've gained some control over otherworldly beings. You can use an action to summon a {@filter fiend or aberration with a challenge rating of 2 or lower|bestiary|source=|challenge rating=[&0;&2]|type=fiend;aberration}, which appears in an unoccupied space that you can see within range. It disappears after 1 hour, when you are {@condition incapacitated}, or when it is reduced to 0 hit points.

The otherworldly being is friendly to you and your companions. In combat, roll initiative for the creature, which has its own turns. It obeys any verbal commands that you issue to it (no action required by you). If you don't issue any commands to the otherworldly being, it attacks the creature you are attacking, or defends itself from hostile creatures if you aren't attacking a creature, but otherwise takes no actions.

Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}. When you reach 17th level in this class, you can summon a {@filter fiend or aberration with a challenge rating of 5 or lower|bestiary|source=|challenge rating=[&0;&5]|type=fiend;aberration} with this feature.

subclassFeature.name: Dimensional Step
entries: At 15th level, you have learned to slip briefly between worlds. You can cast the {@spell dimension door} spell without expending a spell slot. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Cat Burglar
entries: As a cat burglar, you've honed your ability to enter closed or restricted areas, drawing upon a tradition first developed among the catfolk, who often are innately curious and driven to learn what wonders, riches, or unusual friends and foes lie beyond their reach or just out of sight. In ages past, some allowed this inquisitiveness to guide them toward a rogue's life devoted to bridging that gap by breaking into any and all structures, dungeons, or walled-off regions that prevented them from satisfying their curiosity.

So successful were these first catfolk burglars that other rogues soon began emulating their techniques. Walls become but minor inconveniences once you work out the best methods of scaling them and learn to mitigate injuries from falls. In time, cat burglars become adept at breaching any openings they find; after all, if a door was not meant to be opened, why would it have been placed there? Those who devote a lifetime to such endeavors eventually learn to spot and bypass even the cleverest traps and hidden doors, including those disguised or warded by magic.

Some cat burglars use their abilities to help themselves to the contents of treasure vaults or uncover hidden secrets, others become an integral part of an adventuring party that values skillful infiltration techniques, and still others get the jump on their foes by taking the fight to them where and when they least expect it, up to and including private bed chambers or inner sanctums. You'll likely end up someplace you're not supposed to be, but those are the places most worth visiting!

subclassFeature.name: Up, Over, and In
entries: Beginning when you choose this archetype at 3rd level, you have a {@quickref Climbing, Swimming, and Crawling|PHB|4|0|climbing speed} equal to your walking speed. If you already have a {@quickref Climbing, Swimming, and Crawling|PHB|4|0|climbing speed} equal to or greater than your walking speed, it increases by 5 feet. In addition, when you are falling, you can use your reaction to soften the fall. You reduce the {@quickref Falling|XGE|2|0|falling damage} you take by an amount equal to your proficiency bonus + your rogue level. You don't land {@condition prone}, unless the damage you take from the fall would reduce you to less than half your hit point maximum.

subclassFeature.name: Artful Dodger
entries: At 3rd level, alert to the dangers posed by hidden traps and wards, you have advantage on saving throws made to avoid or resist a trap or a magic effect with a trigger, such as the {@spell glyph of warding} spell, and you have resistance to the damage dealt by such effects.

subclassFeature.name: Cat's Eye
entries: Starting at 9th level, you have advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) or Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) checks made to find or disarm traps, locate secret or hidden doors, discern the existence of an illusion, or spot a {@spell glyph of warding}. You can also search for traps while traveling at a {@quickref Travel Pace|PHB|4|0|normal pace}, instead of only while at a {@quickref Travel Pace|PHB|4|0|slow pace}.

subclassFeature.name: Breaking and Entering
entries: At 13th level, when you make an attack against a door, gate, window, shutters, bars, or similar object or structure that is blocking or barring an egress, you have advantage on the attack roll, and you can add your {@classFeature Sneak Attack|Rogue||1} damage on a hit. You can choose for this damage to be audible out to a range of 100 feet or to be audible only within 5 feet of the point where you hit the object or structure. Similarly, you can choose for this damage to appear more or less impactful than it actually is, such as neatly carving a hole for you to squeeze through a wall or window or bursting a door off its hinges.

Your expertise at deftly dismantling crafted works extends to constructs and undead. You don't need advantage on the attack roll to use your {@classFeature Sneak Attack|Rogue||1} feature against constructs and undead. As normal, you can't use {@classFeature Sneak Attack|Rogue||1} if you have disadvantage on the attack roll.

subclassFeature.name: Master Burglar
entries: At 17th level, you can slip past a fire-breathing statue unscathed or tread lightly enough to not set off a pressure plate. The first time on each of your turns that you would trigger a trap or magic effect with a trigger, such as the {@spell glyph of warding} spell, you can choose to not trigger it.

As a bonus action, you can choose a number of creatures equal to your proficiency bonus that you can see within 30 feet of you and grant them the effects of this feature for 1 hour. Once you grant this feature to others, you can't do so again until you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Dawn Blade
entries: Even churches and temples of deities of goodness and light have need of those willing to get their hands dirty and willing to sully their honor in service of what must be done. Dawn blades are devout rogues, drawing divine power from deities of light to strike as a sudden ray of searing sunlight in the darkness. They are often considered controversial by other adherents of their faith, yet the faith's leadership understands such agents are sometimes necessary.

subclassFeature.name: Eyes of the Dawn
entries: At 3rd level, you gain {@sense darkvision} out to a range of 60 feet. If you already have {@sense darkvision}, the range increases by 30 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Dawn Strike
entries: Starting at 3rd level, when you deal damage with your {@classFeature Sneak Attack|Rogue||1} feature, you can magically change the extra damage dealt to radiant damage. When you hit an undead or a creature of shadow with such a {@classFeature Sneak Attack|Rogue||1}, you deal an extra {@damage 1d6} radiant damage.

subclassFeature.name: Radiant Beam
entries: Beginning at 3rd level, when you deal radiant damage to a creature with a melee weapon attack, you can use a bonus action to throw a portion of that radiant energy at a different creature you can see within 30 feet of you. Make a ranged weapon attack against the second creature. You are proficient with this beam, and you don't have disadvantage on the ranged attack roll from being within 5 feet of the first creature (though you can still have disadvantage from other sources). On a hit, the beam deals {@damage 1d6} radiant damage.
When you reach 10th level in this class, the beam's damage increases to {@damage 2d6}.

subclassFeature.name: Bolstering Light
entries: Starting at 9th level, when you reduce a creature to 0 hit points with radiant damage, choose one of the following:

items: Gain {@quickref temporary hit points|PHB|3|0} equal to twice your rogue level for 1 hour.
End one condition affecting you. The condition can be {@condition blinded}, {@condition deafened}, or {@condition poisoned}.
End one curse affecting you.
End one {@condition disease} affecting you.

subclassFeature.name: Sudden Illumination
entries: At 13th level, when you hit a creature with your {@subclassFeature Radiant Beam|Rogue|PHB|Dawn Blade|ToH|3}, it must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or be {@condition blinded} until the end of its next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Dawn Flare
entries: At 17th level, when you use your {@subclassFeature Dawn Strike|Rogue|PHB|Dawn Blade|ToH|3} feature to deal radiant damage to a creature that can't see you, the creature must make a Constitution saving throw.

On a failed save, the creature takes {@damage 10d6} radiant damage and can't regain hit points until the start of your next turn. Once a creature takes damage from this feature, it is immune to your Dawn Flare for 24 hours.

subclassFeature.name: Sapper
entries: You focus as much on identifying the weak points of structures as on the weak points of creatures. Sappers are deployed with the soldiery to dig trenches, build bridges, and breach defenses. When troops move into a heavily defended area, it's your job to make it happen as efficiently as possible.

subclassFeature.name: Combat Engineer
entries: When you select this archetype at 3rd level, you gain proficiency in {@item alchemist's supplies|PHB}, {@item carpenter's tools|PHB}, {@item mason's tools|PHB}, and {@item tinker's tools|PHB}. Using these tools, you can do or create the following.

entries.name: Alchemical Bomb
entries: As an action, you can mix together volatile chemicals into an explosive compound and throw it at a point you can see within 30 feet of you. Each creature within 10 feet of that point must make a Dexterity saving throw, taking {@damage 1d6} force damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Alchemical bombs lose their potency and become inert 1 minute after they are created.

If a construct fails the saving throw or if you throw the bomb at a structure or an object that isn't being worn or carried, your bomb also deals your {@classFeature Sneak Attack|Rogue||1} damage to the target.
When you reach certain levels in this class, the bomb's damage increases: at 5th level ({@damage 2d6}), 11th level ({@damage 3d6}), and 17th level ({@damage 4d6}).

entries.name: Jury Rig Fortification
entries: You are adept at creating fortifications with whatever materials are at hand. With 1 minute of work, you can create one of the following. Your ability to use this option might be limited by the available building materials or if the ground is too hard to work, at the GM's discretion.

items: Create a low wall that is large enough to provide {@quickref Cover|PHB|3|0|half cover} to a Medium creature.
Dig a 5-foot-long, 3-foot-wide trench to a depth of 3 feet.
Build a 5-foot-long, 3-foot-wide ladder. Each additional minute spent on this option increases the length of the ladder by 5 feet. The ladder is sturdy enough to be used as a bridge.

entries.name: Hastily Trap an Area
entries: You can create and set some types of traps quickly. The Creating Traps table indicates the timeframes required to build and deploycommonly used traps. At the GM's discretion, you can use this feature to make and use other types of traps.

entries.caption: Creating Traps
rows: {@bold {@trap Collapsing Roof}}
5 minutes for each 5-foot-by-5-foot section
When you finish building this trap, it is considered set.
{@bold {@trap Falling Net}}
1 minute
1 action
{@bold {@trap Bear Trap|XGE|Hunting Trap}}
1 minute
1 bonus action
{@bold {@trap Pits|DMG|Pit}}

5 minutes for a 5-foot-wide, 10-foot-deep simple pit; 15 minutes for a 5-foot-wide, 10-foot-deep hidden pit; 1 hour for a 5-foot-wide, 10-foot-deep locking pit; to add spikes to a pit, increase the time by 1 minute.
When you finish building this trap, it is considered set. It requires 1 bonus action to reset a simple pit or locking pit and 1 action to reset a hidden pit.

subclassFeature.name: Sculpt Terrain
entries: At 3rd level, when you throw your {@subclassFeature Combat Engineer|Rogue|PHB|Sapper|ToH|3||alchemical bomb}, you can choose for the bomb to not deal damage. If you do so, the area within 10 feet of the point of impact becomes {@quickref difficult terrain|PHB|4|0|Difficult terrain}. You don't need advantage on the attack roll to use your {@classFeature Sneak Attack|Rogue||1} against a creature, if the creature is within the {@quickref difficult terrain|PHB|4|0|Difficult terrain} created by your {@subclassFeature Combat Engineer|Rogue|PHB|Sapper|ToH|3||alchemical bomb}.

subclassFeature.name: Breach Defenses
entries: Starting at 9th level, when you hit a structure or an object that isn't being worn or carried, your attack treats the structure or object as if its damage threshold is 5 lower. For example, if you hit a door that has a damage threshold of 10, its damage threshold is considered 5 when determining if your attack's damage meets or exceeds its threshold. If a structure or object doesn't have a damage threshold or if this feature would allow you to treat its damage threshold as 0 or lower, your attack also deals your {@classFeature Sneak Attack|Rogue||1} damage to the target.
When you reach certain levels in this class, the damage threshold your attacks can ignore increases: at 13th level (10) and 17th level (15).

subclassFeature.name: Clear the Path
entries: At 13th level, you have advantage on checks to disarm traps. If you fail a check made to disarm a trap, the trap doesn't trigger even if its description states otherwise. In addition, you can disarm a trap as a bonus action.

subclassFeature.name: All Clear
entries: Beginning at 17th level, you can use an action to declare a 50-foot-square area safe for travel for 1 minute. Mechanical and magical traps in the area don't trigger for the duration. In addition, {@quickref difficult terrain|PHB|4|0|Difficult terrain} in the area doesn't cost you or any creatures you designate who can see or hear you extra movement when moving through it. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Smuggler
entries: The transport of goods, creatures, and even people can be a lucrative business, particularly if you know how to avoid expensive import and export taxes, bridge, highway, and port tolls, and other legal requirements. Exotic poisons from far-off locales, banned or cursed magic items, and illicit drugs or bootleg liquor all fetch a high price on the black market. Thieves' guilds, pirates, and criminal kingpins pay well to those who can avoid law enforcement when moving stolen goods, provide safe channels of communication, break associates free from jail cells or dungeons, or deliver supplies past guards. You've become adept at all of these things, perhaps even having developed a network of contacts as a criminal, noble, con artist, or sailor during an earlier part of your life.

subclassFeature.name: Dab-handed Dealer
entries: When you choose this archetype at 3rd level, you gain proficiency with {@filter vehicles (land and water)|items|source=|type=vehicle;vehicle (land)} and with your choice of either the {@item disguise kit|PHB} or {@item navigator's tools|PHB}. Moreover, when determining your carrying capacity, you are considered one size category larger than your actual size.

Starting at this level, you also have advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) checks to hide objects on {@filter vehicles|items|source=|type=vehicle;vehicle (land);vehicle(space)}, and you can use the bonus action granted by your {@classFeature Cunning Action|Rogue||2} to make a check to control a vehicle, or to make a Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hand}) check to conceal a {@filter light weapon|items|source=|property=light} on yourself, opposed by the Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks of creatures within 5 feet of you; if you succeed on a check to conceal a weapon in this way, then you have advantage on your next attack against one of those creatures using that weapon, including on ranged attacks even if the target is within 5 feet of you.

subclassFeature.name: Smuggler's Legerdemain
entries: Also at 3rd level, having made a careful study of laws and those who enforce them, you've become adept at avoiding both, even mastering a handful of arcane techniques that aid your smuggling activities. You learn {@filter two cantrips|spells|source=|class=wizard|level=0|school=i;t} at this level and, when you reach 7th level in this class, {@filter one 1st-level spell|spells|source=|class=wizard|level=1|school=i;t} of your choice. The cantrips and spell must be from among the {@filter illusion or transmutation spells on the wizard spell list|spells|source=|class=wizard|school=i;t}, all of which are ideally suited for manipulating goods, duping guards, communicating with covert contacts, or escaping from a failed heist. Having learned these forms of magic through research and rote memorization, Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for these spells.

You can cast the cantrips at will and the spell once at its lowest level; you must finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest} before casting the spell again in this way. You can also cast the spell using any spell slots you have.

Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can replace the 1st-level spell with another 1st-level spell of your choice from among the {@filter illusion or transmutation spells on the wizard spell list|spells|source=|class=wizard|school=i;t}.

subclassFeature.name: Hypervigilance
entries: Starting at 9th level, you have advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight or hearing, and you can't be {@quickref Surprise|PHB|3|0|surprised} while you are conscious. In addition, you have developed an awareness for avoiding social or legal entrapment, and you have advantage on Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) checks to discern loopholes and traps in legal documents and on Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) checks to discern when you are being manipulated into a bad social or legal situation.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Smuggler's Legerdemain
entries: At 13th level, to further facilitate your extralegal activities, you learn a second illusion or transmutation spell, which must be one of the following: {@spell Nystul's magic aura}, {@spell blur}, {@spell darkvision}, {@spell enlarge/reduce}, {@spell invisibility}, {@spell knock}, {@spell levitate}, {@spell magic mouth}, {@spell mirror image}, {@spell rope trick}, or {@spell spider climb}. Intelligence is again your spellcasting ability for this spell. You can cast this spell once at its lowest level and must finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest} before you can cast it again in this way. You can also cast the spell using any spell slots you have of 2nd-level or higher. Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can replace a spell from this list with another from this list.

In addition, beginning at 13th level, whenever you cast one of your 1st-level {@subclassFeature Smuggler's Legerdemain|Rogue|PHB|Smuggler|ToH|3} spells, you always cast it as if using a 2nd-level spell slot unless you choose to cast it using a spell slot you have of a different level.

subclassFeature.name: Slippery as an Eel
entries: Starting at 17th level, you have become especially adept at slipping away from the authorities and getting a jump on foes, even when encumbered by illicit goods. Your speed increases by 10 feet, you ignore {@quickref difficult terrain|PHB|4|0|difficult terrain}, and you have advantage on initiative rolls.

subclassFeature.name: Soulspy
entries: In the eternal war between good and evil, between light and darkness, between life and death, there are many types of participants on each side. Soulspies are agents of the divine who lurk in the shadows, taking a less-visible role in the fight. Occasionally, they aid other agents of their deities, but most often they locate and manage or eliminate threats to their deities that more scrupulous agents might be unwilling or unable to handle.

subclassFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: When you reach 3rd level, you gain the ability to cast spells drawn from the magic of a divine entity.

subclassFeature.name: Cantrips
entries: You learn {@filter three cantrips|spells|source=|class=cleric|level=0} of your choice from the cleric spell list. You learn another cleric cantrip of your choice at 10th level.

subclassFeature.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Soulspy Spellcasting table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your cleric spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend one of these slots at the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.
For example, if you know the 1st-level spell {@spell inflict wounds} and have a 1st-level and a 2nd-level spell slot available, you can cast {@spell inflict wounds} using either slot.

subclassFeature.name: Spells Known of 1st-Level and Higher
entries: You know {@filter three 1st-level cleric spells|spells|source=|class=cleric|level=1} of your choice, two of which you must choose from the {@filter abjuration and necromancy spells on the cleric spell list|spells|source=|class=cleric|school=a;n}. The Spells Known column of the Soulspy Spellcasting table shows when you learn more cleric spells of 1st level or higher. Each of these spells must be an abjuration or necromancy spell and must be of a level for which you have spell slots. The spells you learn at 8th, 14th, and 20th level can be from any school of magic.

When you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the cleric spells you know and replace it with another spell from the cleric spell list. The new spell must be of a level for which you have spell slots, and it must be an abjuration or necromancy spell, unless you're replacing the spell you gained at 3rd, 8th, 14th, or 20th level.

subclassFeature.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for your cleric spells. You learn your spells through meditation and prayer to the powerful forces that guide your actions. You use your Wisdom whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Wisdom modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a cleric spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

subclassFeature.name: Bonus Proficiency
entries: When you choose this archetype at 3rd level, you gain proficiency in the {@skill Religion} skill, if you don't already have it.

subclassFeature.name: Divine Symbol
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you can use an action to create a symbol of your deity that hovers within 5 feet of you. The symbol is a Tiny object that is visible but invulnerable and intangible, and it lasts for 1 minute, until you die, or until you dismiss it (no action required). While this symbol is active, you gain the following benefits:

items: Your Divine Symbol functions as a spellcasting focus for your cleric spells.

As a bonus action, you can turn the symbol into {@item thieves' tools|PHB}, which you can use to pick locks, disarm traps, or any other activities that would normally require such tools. While your Divine Symbol is functioning in this way, it loses all other properties listed here. You can change it from {@item thieves' tools|PHB} back to its symbol form as a bonus action.

The symbol sheds {@quickref Vision and Light|PHB|2|0|bright light} in a 10-foot radius and {@quickref Vision and Light|PHB|2|0|dim light} for an additional 10 feet. You can extinguish or restore the light as a bonus action. When you extinguish the symbol's light, you can also snuff out one candle, torch, or other nonmagical light source within 10 feet of you.

When you create this symbol, and as an action on each of your turns while the symbol is active, you can force the symbol to shoot divine energy at a creature you can see within 30 feet of you. Make a ranged spell attack. On a hit, the target takes {@damage 1d8} radiant or necrotic damage (your choice). When you reach certain levels in this class, the symbol's damage increases: at 5th level ({@damage 2d8}), 11th level ({@damage 3d8}), and 17th level ({@damage 4d8}).

subclassFeature.name: Sacred Stealth
entries: Starting at 9th level, you can use your {@classFeature Sneak Attack|Rogue||1} on a creature hit by an attack with your {@subclassFeature Divine Symbol|Rogue|PHB|Soulspy|ToH|3} if the target of the attack is within 5 feet of an ally, that ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}, and you don't have disadvantage on the attack roll. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (a minimum of once). You regain any expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Touching the Soul
entries: When you reach 13th level, you can use your {@subclassFeature Divine Symbol|Rogue|PHB|Soulspy|ToH|3} to deliver your cleric spells that have a range of touch. Choose a creature you can see within 30 feet of you as the target of the spell. You can't use your {@subclassFeature Sacred Stealth|Rogue|PHB|Soulspy|ToH|9} feature on a spell delivered in this way. After you cast the spell, your {@subclassFeature Divine Symbol|Rogue|PHB|Soulspy|ToH|3} ends.
In addition, when you cast a spell that deals radiant or necrotic damage, you can switch it to do the other type of damage instead.

subclassFeature.name: Life Thief
entries: At 17th level, you gain the ability to magically channel life force energy out of one creature and into another. When you deal radiant or necrotic damage with your {@subclassFeature Divine Symbol|Rogue|PHB|Soulspy|ToH|3} attack or a {@filter cleric spell or cantrip|spells|source=|class=cleric}, choose a friendly creature you can see within 30 feet of you. That creature regains hit points equal to half the radiant or necrotic damage dealt. You can target yourself with this feature. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Underfoot
entries: Though most rogues prefer ambushing their opponents from the shadows, erina rogues ambush their opponents from below. These Underfoot use druidic magic and their natural aptitude for burrowing to defend their forest homes. The Underfoot are an elite order of burrow warriors in every erina colony. Using a combination of guerilla attacks and druidic magic, they are a force to be reckoned with, diving into fights nose-forward.

subclassFeature.name: Restriction: Erina
entries: You can choose this roguish archetype only if you are an {@race erina|ToH}.

subclassFeature.name: Spellcasting
entries: When you reach 3rd level, you gain the ability to cast spells drawn from the magic of the wilds.

subclassFeature.name: Cantrips
entries: You learn three cantrips: {@spell shillelagh} and {@filter two other cantrips of your choice from the druid spell list|spells|source=|class=druid|level=0}. You learn another druid cantrip of your choice at 10th level.

subclassFeature.name: Spell Slots
entries: The Underfoot Spellcasting table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend one of these slots at the spell's level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.
For example, if you know the 1st-level spell {@spell longstrider} and have a 1st-level and a 2nd-level spell slot available, you can cast {@spell longstrider} using either slot.

subclassFeature.name: Spells Known of 1st-Level and Higher
entries: You know {@filter three 1st-level druid spells|spells|source=|class=druid|level=1} of your choice, two of which you must choose from the {@filter divination and transmutation spells on the druid spell list|spells|source=|class=druid|school=d;t}. The Spells Known column of the Underfoot Spellcasting table shows when you learn more druid spells of 1st level or higher. Each of these spells must be an divination or transmutation spell and must be of a level for which you have spell slots. The spells you learn at 8th, 14th, and 20th level can be from any school of magic.

When you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of the druid spells you know and replace it with another spell from the druid spell list. The new spell must be of a level for which you have spell slots, and it must be an divination or transmutation spell, unless you're replacing the spell you gained at 3rd, 8th, 14th, or 20th level.

subclassFeature.name: Spellcasting Ability
entries: Wisdom is your spellcasting ability for your cleric spells. Your magic draws upon your connection with the natural world. You use your Wisdom whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Wisdom modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a druid spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

subclassFeature.name: Versatile Shillelagh
entries: Beginning at 3rd level, when you cast {@spell shillelagh}, the spell is modified in the following ways:

items: Its duration increases to 1 hour.
The spell ends early only if another creature holds the weapon or if the weapon is more than 5 feet away from you for 1 minute or more.
Your {@classFeature Sneak Attack|Rogue||1} feature can be applied to attack rolls made with your {@spell shillelagh} weapon.

subclassFeature.name: Undermine
entries: Beginning at 9th level, you can use your action to dig a hole under a Large or smaller creature within 5 feet of you. That creature must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or fall {@condition prone}. If the target fails its saving throw, you can make one weapon attack against that target as a bonus action.

subclassFeature.name: Death From Below
entries: Beginning at 13th level, when you move at least 10 feet underground toward a target, your next attack against the target with your {@spell shillelagh} weapon has advantage.

subclassFeature.name: Vicious
entries: At 17th level, when you use your {@subclassFeature Death From Below|Rogue|PHB|Underfoot|ToH|13} feature and hit the target with your {@spell shillelagh} weapon, the target is {@condition restrained} by vegetation and soil until the end of its next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Black Powder Sorcery
entries: Your innate magic comes from the explosive power of raw alchemy and black powder. You parents may have been alchemists, whose long exposure to alchemical reagents mingled with a latent talent for magic in their bloodlines and caused you to be born with such abilities. Or you may have been experimented upon—with or without your permission—when you were younger and those alchemical experiments brought this unexpected magical power to the surface. Whatever the catalyst for your powers, they bring with them an affinity for black powder, allowing you magical prowess that exploits its power to your benefit.

subclassFeature.name: Gun Mage
entries: At 1st level, you gain proficiency with {@filter simple firearms|items|source=|type=simple weapon;firearm=sand} and with the {@item musket|ToH} (see the Adventuring Gear chapter for details on these weapons), and you gain proficiency with {@item alchemist's supplies|PHB} or {@item gunsmith's tools|ToH} (your choice). In addition, you learn the {@spell mage hand} cantrip if you don't already know it.

subclassFeature.name: Gun Hand
entries: Starting at 1st level, when you cast {@spell mage hand}, you can perform the following additional tasks with it:

items: You can use your {@spell mage hand} to draw or stow a pistol on your person or pick up a firearm within 5 feet of you that isn't being worn or carried. You can do this once on each of your turns for free, during either your move or your action.

You can use a bonus action to reload a {@item pistol|ToH} held by your {@spell mage hand}. Your {@spell mage hand} visibly becomes a pair of spectral hands to complete this action, the second hand vanishing once the pistol is loaded.

When a creature within 5 feet of you attacks you with a melee weapon, you can use a reaction to fire a {@item pistol|ToH} held by your {@spell mage hand} at the attacker. Being within 5 feet of the target doesn't impose disadvantage on the attack roll.

entries: You can create multiple {@spell mage hand|PHB|mage hands} with this feature when you reach higher levels. You gain a second {@spell mage hand} at 5th level, and an additional {@spell mage hand} at 9th, 13th, and 17th level. Unlike your primary {@spell mage hand}, these additional {@spell mage hand|PHB|mage hands} can be used only for the tasks described under this feature and any other aspects of this class that reference this feature. Each extra {@spell mage hand} remains within 5 feet of you and vanishes if it is unable to remain within 5 feet of you.

subclassFeature.name: Fusillade
entries: Also at 1st level, when you use the {@action Attack} action, you can make the attack with a weapon you are wielding or with a {@item pistol|ToH} held in one of your {@spell mage hand|PHB|mage hands}. When you attack with a {@item pistol|ToH} held in one of your {@spell mage hand|PHB|mage hands}, you can use your Charisma modifier, instead of Dexterity, for the attack and damage rolls.

In addition, when you reach 2nd level, you can use an action and spend 1 or more {@classFeature sorcery points|Sorcerer||2} to magically reload and fire a {@item pistol|ToH} held in one of your {@spell mage hand|PHB|mage hands}. The ammunition fired is magically created and dissipates after being fired, hit or miss. For each {@classFeature sorcery points|Sorcerer||2||sorcery point} you spend, you can magically reload and fire another {@item pistol|ToH} held in another of your {@spell mage hand|PHB|mage hands} as part of the same action. These attacks have a range of 30 feet. Attacks from your {@spell mage hand}-held {@item pistol|ToH|pistols} can attack separate targets or the same target, dealing damage, including the possibility of a {@variantrule Gunpowder Burst|ToH|burst}, as normal on a hit. Each {@spell mage hand}'s attack counts as a separate attack for the purposes of determining the number of bursts that can happen. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Magic Bullets
entries: Beginning at 6th level, your attacks with {@filter firearms|items|source=|property=firearm} count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage. In addition, when you make an attack with a {@filter firearm|items|source=|property=firearm}, you can spend 1 {@classFeature sorcery points|Sorcerer||2||sorcery point} to imbue the attack with elemental energy. Choose one of the following: acid, cold, fire, lightning, or thunder. On a hit, an imbued attack deals an extra {@damage 2d6} damage of the chosen type. At 14th level, you can spend 2 {@classFeature sorcery points|Sorcerer||2} instead, increasing the damage to {@damage 4d6}.

subclassFeature.name: Absorb Power
entries: At 14th level, you can replenish your sorcerous power by absorbing the latent energy of black powder. In a ritual that takes 1 minute, you can absorb the power in up to 30 cartridges' worth of black powder (equivalent to a full gunpowder horn). For every 10 cartridges worth of gunpowder, you regain 1 expended {@classFeature sorcery points|Sorcerer||2||sorcery point}. The black powder is consumed in the process. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Ensuing Shot
entries: At 18th level, when you use your action to cast a spell using a spell slot of 4th level or lower, you can make one attack with a {@item pistol|ToH} as a bonus action. This {@item pistol|ToH} can be held by you or by one of your {@spell mage hand|PHB|mage hands}. If you spend 6 {@classFeature sorcery points|Sorcerer||2}, you can make one attack with each {@item pistol|ToH} held by you and your {@spell mage hand|PHB|mage hands} instead.

subclassFeature.name: Cold-Blooded
entries: The serpentfolk slithered across the surface of the world in the primordial times before the warm-blooded races became dominant. They worked their will upon the land and ocean and created works to show their mastery of the magical arts. Their artistry did not end with the landscape. They also experimented on any warm-blooded creatures they captured until they had warped and molded the creatures into new and deadly forms.

One or more of your ancestors was experimented on or an associate of the world's earliest serpentfolk. Your ancestor's natural affinity for magic was nurtured, expanded, and warped by the experimentation of their ophidian masters in order to transform them into something closer to the serpentine ideal. Those alterations made so long ago have waxed in you, allowing you to influence intelligent creatures more easily. Now you must decide if you will follow the serpent's path of dominance and subjugation or if you will fight against their influence and use your power for a greater purpose.

subclassFeature.name: Ophidian Metabolism
entries: At 1st level, your affinity with serpents grants you a measure of their hardiness. You can go without food for a number of days equal to 3 + your Constitution modifier (minimum 1) + your proficiency bonus before you suffer the effects of {@quickref food and water|PHB|2|0|starvation}. You also have advantage on saving throws against poison and disease.

subclassFeature.name: Patterned Scales
entries: Also at 1st level, when you use magic to trick or deceive, the residual energy of your spell subtly alters how others perceive you. When you cast an {@filter illusion spell|spells|source=|school=i} using a spell slot of 1st level or higher, you have advantage on Charisma ({@skill Deception}) and Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) checks for the duration of the spell and for 10 minutes after the spell's duration ends.

subclassFeature.name: Insinuating Serpent
entries: Starting at 6th level, even when a creature resists your unsettling allure, your presence gets under their skin. When you cast an {@filter enchantment or illusion spell|spells|source=|school=e;i} using a spell slot of 1st level or higher, and your target succeeds on its saving throw against your spell, your target becomes {@condition charmed} by you until the start of your next turn. If the spell you cast affects multiple targets, only one of those targets can be affected by this feature.

subclassFeature.name: Spirit Venom
entries: At 14th level, you sap the will and resolve of creatures that are under your sway. If you start your turn with at least one creature within 30 feet of you that is currently {@condition charmed}, {@condition frightened}, {@condition paralyzed}, {@condition restrained}, or {@condition stunned} by a spell you cast or a magical effect you created, such as from a magic item, you can use your reaction to force each such creature to take {@damage 6d4} psychic damage.

You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}. If you have expended all your uses of this feature, you can spend 5 {@classFeature sorcery points|Sorcerer||2} at the start of your turn to use it again.

subclassFeature.name: Mirrored Lamina
entries: Starting at 18th level, when you fail a saving throw against being {@condition charmed}, {@condition frightened}, {@condition paralyzed}, {@condition restrained}, or {@condition stunned} by a spell or other magical effect, you can use your reaction to force the creature that cast the spell or created the magical effect to succeed on a saving throw against your spell save DC or suffer the same condition for the same duration.

If both you and the creature that targeted you are affected by a condition as a result of this feature and that condition allows for subsequent saving throws to end the effect, the condition ends for both of you if either one of you succeeds on a subsequent saving throw.

subclassFeature.name: Hungering
entries: Your innate magic comes from a deep, primal source of hunger and craving. Perhaps your line was cursed for its greed by a god of plenty or generosity. Perhaps one of your forebears was marked by the hungering undead. Sorcerers with this origin have an unyielding appetite for arcana and go to nearly any length to satiate their desire to increase their magical power.

subclassFeature.name: Hungry Eyes
entries: At 1st level, you can sense when a creature is nearing death. You know if a creature you can see that isn't undead or a construct within 30 feet of you is below half its hit point maximum. Your spell attacks ignore {@quickref Cover|PHB|3|0|half cover and three-quarters cover} when targeting creatures you sense with this feature.

subclassFeature.name: Thirsty Soul
entries: Beginning at 1st level, when you reduce a hostile creature to 0 hit points, you regain hit points equal to your sorcerer level + your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1). This feature can restore you to no more than half your hit point maximum.

subclassFeature.name: Feast of Arcana
entries: Starting at 6th level, when you reduce one or more hostile creatures to 0 hit points with one spell of 1st level or higher, you regain 1 spent {@classFeature sorcery points|Sorcerer||2||sorcery point}.

subclassFeature.name: Glutton for Punishment
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can use your reaction to intentionally fail a saving throw against a spell that deals damage and that was cast by a hostile creature. If you do so, you regain a number of spent {@classFeature sorcery points|Sorcerer||2} equal to half your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1).

subclassFeature.name: Greedy Heart
entries: At 18th level, when you spend {@classFeature sorcery points|Sorcerer||2} to create spell slots or use metamagic, you reduce the cost by 1 {@classFeature sorcery points|Sorcerer||2||sorcery point} (this can't reduce the cost below 1).

subclassFeature.name: Resonant Body
entries: You are a conduit for the power that exists in sounds and vibrations, your body a living tuning fork capable of emitting, focusing, muting, and transmuting sound and sonic forms of magic. Perhaps you endured overexposure to transmutation magic, arcane thunder, or the ear-splitting cries of an androsphinx, bukavac (see Tome of Beasts), or avalanche screamer (see Tome of Beasts 2). Maybe you can trace your lineage to an ancestor who spent an extended period on a plane dominated by elemental lightning and thunder or by unceasing screams of madness; you yourself may have been born on such a cacophonous plane. Alternately, you or a forebear may have suffered prolonged exposure to the deafening thunderclaps of a bronze dragon's lair. Or you may even have been experimented on by aboleths or other maniacal spellcasters, escaping before the transformation was complete....

Whatever its source, resonant magic infuses your very existence, causing you to manifest one or more unusual characteristics. At your option, you can create a quirk or roll a d6 and consult the Resonant Body Quirks table to determine a quirk for your character.

entries.caption: Resonant Body Quirks
rows: You emit a faint hum, audible to any creature within 5 feet of you.
In response to natural or magical thunder, your body flickers into brief transparency with the sound of each thunderclap.
Beasts with the Keen Hearing trait initially respond aggressively when you come within 30 feet of them.
If you hold a delicate, nonmagical glass object such as a crystal wine glass for longer than one round, the object shatters.
Every time you speak, your voice randomly changes in pitch, tone, and/or resonance, so that you never sound quite the same.
When another living creature touches you, you emit a brief, faint tone like a chime, the volume of which increases with the force of the touch.

subclassFeature.name: Signature Sound
entries: At 1st level, you harbor sonic vibrations within you. You are immune to the {@condition deafened} condition, and you have {@sense tremorsense|MM} out to a range of 10 feet. In addition, you have advantage on saving throws against effects that deal thunder damage.
When you reach 3rd level in this class, you have resistance to thunder damage, and at 6th level, your {@sense tremorsense|MM} extends to 20 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Reverberating Quintessence
entries: Starting at 1st level, you can cast the {@spell alarm} spell (audible option only) once without expending a spell slot or requiring material components. Once you cast alarm in this way, you can't do so again until you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.
When you reach 3rd level in this class, you can expend 3 sorcery points to cast the {@spell shatter} or {@spell silence} spell without expending a spell slot or requiring material components.

subclassFeature.name: Sonic Savant
entries: Beginning at 6th level, whenever you use a {@classFeature Metamagic|Sorcerer||3} option on a spell that deals thunder damage, deafens creatures, or silences or magnifies sounds, you expend only a fraction of your effort to do so. With these sorts of spells, {@classFeature Metamagic|Sorcerer||3} options that normally cost only 1 {@classFeature sorcery points|Sorcerer||2||sorcery point} instead cost 0 {@classFeature sorcery points|Sorcerer||2}; all other {@classFeature Metamagic|Sorcerer||3} options cost half the normal number of {@classFeature sorcery points|Sorcerer||2} (rounded up).

You can use your Sonic Savant feature to reduce the cost of a number of {@classFeature Metamagic|Sorcerer||3} options equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Sound and Fury
entries: At 14th level, your resistance to thunder damage becomes immunity. In addition, when you cast a spell that deals damage, you can change the damage type to thunder. If the spell also imposes a condition on a creature damaged by the spell, you can choose to impose the {@condition deafened} condition instead. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Resounding Spellcasting
entries: Beginning when you reach 18th level, any of your cantrips that deal thunder damage affect even those creatures that avoid the brunt of the effect. When a creature succeeds on a saving throw against a cantripthat deals thunder damage, the creature takes half the cantrip's damage but suffers no additional effect from the cantrip.

Moreover, you can increase the power of some of your spells. When you cast {@filter a sorcerer spell of 1st through 5th level that deals thunder damage|spells|source=|level=1;2;3;4;5|class=sorcerer|damage type=thunder}, you can cause the spell to maximize its damage dice. Once you use this feature, you shouldn't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}. Each time you use it again, you take {@damage 2d12} force damage for each level of the spell you cast. This force damage ignores any resistance or immunity to force damage you might have.

subclassFeature.name: Rifthopper
entries: Rifthoppers are the living embodiment of wanderlust. The yearn to travel and witness unseen vistas burns in them and manifests in their ability to move nearly at the speed of thought. The origin of the rifthoppers' powers remains a mystery, as they refuse to stay in one place long enough to be studied extensively. Given the lack of empirical evidence, many scholars have hypothesized that rifthoppers absorb energy from the world itself, typically through an innate connection with ley lines or with areas where the borders between planes are thin, and can use it to alter their own magic.

Adventuring rifthoppers often concern themselves with investigating mysterious portals to unknown locations, researching ley lines and other mystic phenomena, or seeking out and stopping spatial and temporal disturbances.

subclassFeature.name: Teleport Object
entries: Starting at 1st level, you can use an action to teleport a small object that isn't being worn or carried and that you can see within 30 feet of you into your hand. Alternatively, you can teleport an object from your hand to a space you can see within 30 feet of you. The object can weigh no more than 5 pounds and must be able to fit into a 1-foot cube.
The weight of the object you can teleport increases when you reach certain levels in this class: at 6th (10 pounds), 14th level (15 pounds), and 18th level (20 pounds).

subclassFeature.name: Shift Space
entries: At 1st level, once on each of your turns, you can spend an amount of movement equal to up to half your speed and teleport to an unoccupied space you can see within a number of feet equal to the movement you spent. If your speed is 0, such as from being {@condition grappled} or {@condition restrained}, you can't use this feature.

When you reach 3rd level in this class, you can spend movement equal to your full speed, reducing your speed to 0 for the turn, and expend a spell slot of 2nd level or higher to teleport yourself to a destination within range. The range you can travel is dependent on the level of the spell slot expended as detailed in the Rifthopper Teleportation Distance table. You bring any objects you are wearing or carrying with you when you teleport, as long as their weight doesn't exceed your carrying capacity. If you teleport into an occupied space, you take {@damage 4d6} force damage and are pushed to the nearest unoccupied space.

entries.caption: Rifthopper Teleportation Distance
rows: 2nd
30 feet
3rd
60 feet
4th
120 feet
5th
240 feet
6th
480 feet
7th or higher
960 feet

subclassFeature.name: Tactical Swap
entries: At 6th level, when a creature you can see within 60 feet of you starts its turn or when you or a creature you can see within 60 feet of you is attacked, you can use your reaction to swap positions with the creature. The target must be willing.
If you use this feature when you or another creature is attacked, the attack's target becomes the creature that now occupies the space being attacked, not the original target.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Familiar Locations
entries: Starting at 14th level, if you spend an hour in a location, familiarizing yourself with its features and noting its peculiarities, you can use an action to teleport yourself and a number of willing creatures equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1) within 30 feet of you and that you can see to the location. You can teleport to this location over any distance as long as both you and it are on the same plane of existence. If the location is mobile, such as a boat or wagon, you can't familiarize yourself with it enough to use this feature.

You can be familiar with a number of locations equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1). You can choose to forget a location (no action required) to make room for familiarizing yourself with a new location.
You can teleport creatures with this feature a number of times per day equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Dimensional Ambler
entries: Starting at 18th level, you can use an action to transport yourself and a number of willing creatures equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1) within 30 feet of you and that you can see to the Astral Plane or to the Ethereal Plane. While you are on these planes, you and the creatures you transported can move normally, but each transported creature must stay within 60 feet of you. You can choose to return all of you to the Material Plane at any time as a bonus action. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Spore Sorcery
entries: One of the most omnipresent elements in the atmosphere is practically invisible and often ignored: spores. Plants of all varieties, fungal sentient life forms like mushroomfolk, and even animals emit these tiny pieces of life. You've always had an affinity for the natural world, and your innate magic is carried within the power of these omnipresent spores.

Spore sorcerers are regularly found among the mushroomfolk and derro who grow large gardens of fungi deep beneath the surface of the world. Spore sorcerers can also be found in any area with an abundance of plant life, such as forests, swamps, and deep jungles.

subclassFeature.name: Nature Magic
entries: Your affinity with the natural world and the spores that exist between all plants and creatures allows you to learn spells from the druid class. When your {@classFeature Spellcasting|Sorcerer||1} feature lets you learn or replace a sorcerer cantrip or a sorcerer spell of 1st level or higher, you can choose the new spell from the {@filter druid spell list|spells|source=|class=druid} or the {@filter sorcerer spell list|spells|source=|class=sorcerer}. You must otherwise obey the restrictions for selecting the spell, and it becomes a sorcerer spell for you.

In addition, when you reach 5th level in this class, you can cast {@spell speak with plants} without expending a spell slot a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Spore Transmission
entries: At 1st level, your spores allow you to communicate with creatures telepathically. You can use a bonus action to create a telepathic link with one creature you can see within 30 feet of you. Until the link ends, you can telepathically speak to the target, and, if it understands at least one language, it can speak telepathically to you. The link lasts for 10 minutes or until you use another bonus action to break the link or to establish this link with a different creature.

If the target is unwilling, it can make a Charisma saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the link on a success. If an unwilling target ends the link in this way, you can't establish a link with that target again for 24 hours.

subclassFeature.name: Metamagic Spore Transmission
entries: Starting at 6th level, the spores connecting you and the target of your {@subclassFeature Spore Transmission|Sorcerer|PHB|Spore|ToH|1} enhance your metamagic effects on the linked target. You gain the following benefits when using the indicated {@classFeature Metamagic|Sorcerer||3} options:

entries.name: Careful Spell
entries: If the spell allows a target to take only half damage on a successful saving throw, the linked target instead takes no damage.

entries.name: Distant Spell
entries: When you use this Metamagic option to increase the range of a touch spell, the spell's range is 60 feet when cast on the linked target.

entries.name: Extended Spell
entries: If cast on the linked target, the spell's duration is tripled rather than doubled, to a maximum of 36 hours.

entries.name: Hungry Spell
entries: If the linked target is reduced to 0 hit points with your hungry spell, you regain hit points equal to double your Charisma modifier (minimum of 2).

entries.name: Lingering Spell
