Water
Amphibians

subclassFeature.name: Expanded Spell List
entries: Animal Lords let you choose from an expanded list of spells when you learn a warlock spell. The Animal Lord Expanded Spells table shows the animal lord spells that are added to the warlock spell list for you, along with the spells associated with your patron's affinity: air, earth, or water.

entries.caption: Animal Lords Expanded Spells
rows: 1st
{@spell speak with animals}
{@spell thunderwave}
{@spell longstrider}
{@spell fog cloud}
2nd
{@spell mark prey|ToH}*
{@spell gust of wind}
{@spell pass without trace}
{@spell misty step}
3rd
{@spell conjure animals}
{@spell fly}
{@spell phantom steed}
{@spell water breathing}
4th
{@spell polymorph}
{@spell storm of wings|ToH}*
{@spell sudden stampede|ToH}*
{@spell control water}
5th
{@spell commune with nature}
{@spell insect plague}
{@spell insect plague}
{@spell cloudkill}

subclassFeature.name: Natural Blessing
entries: Starting at 1st level, you learn the {@spell druidcraft} cantrip, and you gain proficiency in the {@skill Animal Handling} skill.

subclassFeature.name: Animalistic Insight
entries: At 1st level, your patron bestows upon you the ability to discern your foe's flaws to aid in its downfall. You can use an action to analyze one creature you can see within 30 feet of you and impart this information to your companions. You and a number of creatures within 30 feet of you equal to your proficiency bonus each gain one of the following benefits (your choice). This benefit lasts for 1 minute or until the analyzed creature dies.

items: You gain a +1 bonus to attack rolls against the analyzed creature.
You gain a +1 bonus to the damage roll when you hit the analyzed creature with an attack.
You have advantage on saving throws against the spells and effects of the analyzed creature.
When the analyzed creature attacks you, you gain a +1 bonus to Armor Class.

entries: Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}. When you reach 10th level in this class, each +1 bonus increases to +2.

subclassFeature.name: Patron Companion
entries: At 6th level, your patron sends you a beast companion that accompanies you on your adventures and is trained to fight alongside you. The companion acts as the animal lord's eyes and ears, allowing your patron to watch over you, and, at times, advise, warn, or otherwise communicate with you.

Choose a beast that relates to your patron (as shown in the Beast Type column in the Animal Lords table) that has a {@filter challenge rating of 1/4 or lower|bestiary|Challenge Rating=[&0;&1/4]|type=beast}. If you have the {@filter Pact of the Chain|optionalfeatures|feature type=pb} {@classFeature Pact Boon|Warlock||3}, this beast becomes your familiar.

Your patron companion is friendly to you and your companions, and you can speak with it as if you shared a language. It obeys your commands and, in combat, it shares your initiative and takes its turn immediately after yours. Your patron companion can move and use its reaction on its own, but, if you don't issue any commands to it, the only action it takes is the {@action Dodge} action. You can use a bonus action to direct it to take the {@action Attack}, {@action Dash}, {@action Disengage}, {@action Help}, {@action Hide}, or {@action Search} action or an action listed in its statistics. If you are {@condition incapacitated}, the companion can take any action of its choice, not just {@action Dodge}.

If your companion dies, your patron sends a new one to you after 24 hours. If your patron companions die too often, your patron might be reluctant to send a new one or might reprimand you in other ways.

subclassFeature.name: Primal Mastery
entries: At 10th level, you can use your bond to your patron to tap into the innate connection between all animals. At the end of each {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}, choose one of the following benefits. The benefit lasts until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.

entries.name: Cat Eyes
entries: You have {@sense darkvision} out to a range of 60 feet. If you already have {@sense darkvision}, its range increases by 30 feet.

entries.name: Chameleonic
entries: You have advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks.

entries.name: Fangs
entries: You grow fangs. The fangs are a natural melee weapon, which you can use to make unarmed strikes. When you hit with your fangs, you can use Charisma instead of Strength for the attack, and your fangs deal piercing damage equal to {@damage 1d6} + your Charisma modifier, instead of the bludgeoning damage normal for an unarmed strike.

entries.name: Hold Breath
entries: You can hold your breath for 10 minutes.

entries.name: Keen Senses
entries: You have advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

entries.name: Leap
entries: Your jump distance is doubled.

entries.name: Spry
entries: You have advantage on Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) checks.

entries.name: Swift
entries: Your speed increases by 10 feet.

entries.name: Thick Hide
entries: You gain a +1 bonus to your Armor Class.

entries.name: Webbed Limbs
entries: You have a {@quickref Climbing, Swimming, and Crawling|PHB|4|0|swimming speed} of 20 feet.

subclassFeature.name: Call the Legions
entries: At 14th level, you can summon a horde of beasts to come to your aid. As an action, you call upon your animal lord, and several beasts of your patron's type appear in unoccupied spaces that you can see within 60 feet of you. This works like a 7th-level {@spell conjure animals} spell, except you don't need to maintain {@condition concentration}. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Hunter in Darkness
entries: The Hunter in Darkness is an entity that sees all creatures as prey and enjoys instilling fear in its prey. It prefers intelligent prey over mere beasts, as their fear tastes so much sweeter. Hunters who display impressive prowess for hunting pique its interest. The Hunter in Darkness often bestows its power on such individuals to spread fear further than the Hunter can by itself.

Though your patron isn't mindless, it cares only for the thrill of the hunt and the spreading of fear. It cares not what you do with the power it grants you beyond that. Your connection with the Hunter can sometimes cause changes in your worldview. You might view every creature you meet as either predator or prey, or you might face problems with a "kill or be killed" attitude.

subclassFeature.name: Expanded Spell List
entries: The Hunter in Darkness lets you choose from an expanded list of spells when you learn a warlock spell. The following spells are added to the warlock spell list for you.

entries.caption: Hunter in Darkness Expanded Spells
rows: 1st
{@spell bloodhound|ToH}*, {@spell hunter's endurance|ToH}*
2nd
{@spell instant snare|ToH}*, {@spell mark prey|ToH}*
3rd
{@spell clairvoyance}, {@spell nondetection}
4th
{@spell harry|ToH}*, {@spell heart-seeking arrow|ToH}*
5th
{@spell killing fields|ToH}*, {@spell legend lore}

subclassFeature.name: Savage Hunter
entries: Starting at 1st level, when you reduce a hostile creature to 0 hp, its nearest ally within 30 feet of you must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw against your warlock spell save DC or be {@condition frightened} of you until the end of its next turn.

subclassFeature.name: The Hunter in Darkness and Your Pact Boons
entries: When you select your {@classFeature pact boon|Warlock||3} at 3rd level, it is altered by your patron in the following ways.

entries.name: Pact of the Chain
entries: Your familiar is a hunting hound made of shadow, and it uses the statistics of a {@creature wolf|MM}.

entries.name: Pact of the Blade
entries: Your pact weapon can be a {@item longbow|PHB} or {@item shortbow|PHB} in addition to a melee weapon. You must provide arrows for the weapon.

entries.name: Pact of the Tome
entries: Your tome contains descriptions of tracks made by a multitude of creatures. If you consult your tome for 1 minute while inspecting tracks, you can identify the type of creature that left the tracks (such as a winter wolf), though not the creature's name or specific appearance (such as Frosttooth, the one-eyed leader of a notorious pack of winter wolves that terrorizes the area).

subclassFeature.name: Step Into Shadow
entries: Beginning at 6th level, you can disappear into darkness and reappear next to an enemy. As a bonus action while in {@quickref Vision and Light|PHB|2|0|dim light or darkness}, you can disappear in a puff of inky smoke and reappear in an unoccupied space that is also in {@quickref Vision and Light|PHB|2|0|dim light or darkness} within 5 feet of a creature within 30 feet of you. If that creature is {@condition frightened} and you attack it, you have advantage on the attack roll. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Strike from the Dark
entries: Beginning at 10th level, your patron's constant hunger for fear inures you to it. You are immune to being {@condition frightened}. In addition, when you are in {@quickref Vision and Light|PHB|2|0|dim light or darkness} and you hit a creature with a weapon attack, it must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw against your warlock spell save DC or be {@condition frightened} of you for 1 minute or until it takes any damage.

subclassFeature.name: Avatar of Death
entries: Starting at 14th level, if you reduce a target to 0 hp with a weapon attack, you can use a bonus action to force each ally of the target within 30 feet of you to make a Wisdom saving throw against your warlock spell save DC. On a failure, the creature is {@condition frightened} of you for 1 minute or until it takes any damage. If a creature is immune to being {@condition frightened}, it is instead {@condition stunned} until the end of its next turn. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Old Wood
entries: You have made a pact with the ancient intelligence of a primeval forest. Before the rise of human civilization, before the time of the elves, before even the dragons, there were the forests. Empires rise and fall around them, but the forests remain as a testament to nature's endurance.

However, times are changing, and the unchecked growth of civilization threatens the green. The intelligences that imbue the antediluvian forests seek emissaries in the world that can act beyond their boughs, and one has heard your call for power. You are a guardian of the Old Wood, a questing branch issuing from a vast, slumbering intelligence sent to act on its behalf, perhaps even to excise these lesser beings from its borders.

subclassFeature.name: Expanded Spell List
entries: Your connection to the forest allows you to choose from an expanded list of spells when you learn a warlock spell. The following spells are added to the warlock spell list for you.

entries.caption: Old Wood Expanded Spells
rows: 1st
{@spell animal friendship}, {@spell faerie fire}
2nd
{@spell animal messenger}, {@spell spike growth}
3rd
{@spell conjure animals}, {@spell protection from energy}
4th
{@spell conjure woodland beings}, {@spell giant insect}
5th
{@spell greater restoration}, {@spell tree stride}

subclassFeature.name: Sap Magic
entries: At 1st level, your patron bestows upon you the ability to absorb magic from nearby spellcasting. When a creature casts a spell of a level you can cast or lower within 30 feet of you, you can use your reaction to.

subclassFeature.name: Forest's Defender
entries: At 1st level, your patron gifts you with the skills necessary to defend it. You gain proficiency with {@item shield|PHB|shields}, and you learn the {@spell shillelagh} cantrip. {@spell Shillelagh} counts as a warlock cantrip for you, but it doesn't count against your number of cantrips known.

subclassFeature.name: The Old Wood and Your Pact Boons
entries: When you select your {@classFeature pact boon|Warlock||3} at 3rd level, it is altered by your patron in the following ways.

entries.name: Pact of the Chain
entries: When you conjure your familiar or change its form, you can choose the form of an {@creature awakened shrub|MM} or {@creature child of the briar|ToB} (see Tome of Beasts) in addition to the usual familiar choices.

entries.name: Pact of the Blade
entries: The blade of the Old Wood is a weapon made of wood and thorns and grows out of your palm. When you cast {@spell shillelagh}, your Pact Blade is affected by the spell, regardless of the form your Pact Blade takes.

entries.name: Pact of the Tome
entries: The Old Wood grows a tome for you. The tome's cover is hardened bark from the forest's native trees, and its pages are leaves whose color changes with the seasons. If you want to add a new spell to your book, you must first plant it in the ground. After 1 hour, the book emerges from the soil with the new spell inscribed on its leaves. If your tome is lost or destroyed, you must return to your patron forest for it to grow you a new one.

subclassFeature.name: Predatory Grace
entries: Starting at 6th level, you are able to cast {@spell pass without trace} without expending a spell slot. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}. In addition, {@quickref difficult terrain|PHB|4|0|difficult terrain} caused by roots, underbrush, and other natural forest terrain costs you no extra movement. You can pass through nonmagical plants without being slowed by them and without taking damage from them if they have thorns, spines, or a similar hazard.

subclassFeature.name: Nature's Endurance
entries: At 10th level, your patron has suffused your body with a portion of its ability to withstand harmful magic. You gain resistance to damage from spells of a level you can cast or lower.

subclassFeature.name: Avatar of the Wood
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can channel the power of the forest to physically transform, taking on many of its aspects. Your legs, arms, and torso elongate, your body becomes covered in thick, dark bark, and branches sprout from your head as your hair recedes. You can transform as a bonus action and the transformation lasts 1 minute. While transformed, you gain the following benefits:

items: Your Armor Class is 16 plus your Dexterity modifier.
You gain {@sense tremorsense|MM} with a radius of 30 feet, and your attacks can reach 5 feet further.

Your hands become branch-like claws, and you can use the {@action Attack} action to attack with the claws. You are proficient with the claws, and the claws count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage. You add your Charisma modifier to your attack and damage rolls with the claws. The damage is slashing and the damage die is a {@damage d6}. If you have the {@classFeature pact boon|Warlock||3||Pact of the Blade} feature, your claw attack benefits from your invocations as if it was a pact weapon.

Your {@subclassFeature Sap Magic|Warlock|PHB|Old Wood|ToH|1} feature changes to Arcasynthesis: When a spell of 5th level or lower is cast within 60 feet of you, you can use your reaction to synthesize the magic. The spell resolves as normal, but you have a 50 percent chance of regaining {@damage 1d10} hp per level of the spell cast.

entries: Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Primordial
entries: Some who search for power settle on lesser gods or demon lords, others delve into deeper mysteries until they touch elder entities. These great entities build worlds, crafting mountains and species as if sculpting clay, or annihilate them utterly. Embodying creation, destruction, and the land itself, your patron is an ancient power beyond mortal understanding.

Primordials stand in opposition to the Great Old Ones, the other side of the scale that maintains the balance of reality. Your primordial patron speaks to you in the language of omens, dreams, or intuition, and may call upon you to defend the natural world, to root out the forces of the Void, or even to manipulate seemingly random people or locations for reasons known only to their unfathomable purpose. While you can't grasp the full measure of your patron's designs, as long as your bond is strong, there is nothing that can stand in your way.

subclassFeature.name: Expanded Spell List
entries: The Primordial lets you choose from an expanded list of spells when you learn a warlock spell. The following spells are added to the warlock spell list for you.

entries.caption: Primordial Expanded Spells
rows: 1st
{@spell command}, {@spell healing word}
2nd
{@spell lesser restoration}, {@spell mud|ToH}*
3rd
{@spell power word fling|ToH}*, {@spell revivify}
4th
{@spell power word rend|ToH}*, {@spell stone shape}
5th
{@spell conjure elemental}, {@spell creation}

subclassFeature.name: Convulsion of the Worldbuilder
entries: At 1st level, you can use an action to call upon the bond between your primordial patron and the world it created to ripple shockwaves through the ground. Choose a point you can see within 60 feet of you, then choose if the ripples happen in a 30-foot cone, a 30-foot line that is 5 feet wide, or a 20-foot-radius burst. The ripples originate from or are centered on the point you chose, depending on the form the ripples take. Each creature in the cone, line, or burst must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or take {@damage 1d8} bludgeoning damage and be knocked {@condition prone}. If the ground in the area is loose earth or stone, it becomes {@quickref difficult terrain|PHB|4|0} until the rubble is cleared. Each 5-foot-diameter portion of the area requires at least 1 minute to clear by hand.

Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}. When you reach certain levels in this class, the damage increases: at 5th level ({@damage 2d8}), 11th level ({@damage 3d8}), and 17th level ({@damage 4d8}).

subclassFeature.name: Redirection
entries: At 6th level, you learn to channel the reality-bending powers of your patron to avoid attacks. When a creature you can see attacks only you, you can use your reaction to redirect the attack to a target of your choice within range of the attacker's weapon or spell. If no other target is within range, you can't redirect the attack.
If the attack is from a spell of 4th level or higher, you must succeed on an ability check using your spellcasting ability to redirect it. The DC equals
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Adaptive Shroud
entries: At 10th level, your bond with your patron protects you by adapting itself when you are injured. When you take damage, you can use your reaction to gain resistance to the triggering damage type until the start of your next turn. If you expend a spell slot as part of this reaction, the resistance lasts for a number of rounds equal to your proficiency bonus. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Crushing Regard of the Primordial One
entries: At 14th level, you learn to direct the weight of your patron's infinite gaze onto the unworthy. You can use an action to cause of the following effects. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

entries.name: One Creature
entries: One creature you can see within 60 feet of you must make a Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes {@damage 10d10} force damage and is {@condition paralyzed} for 1 minute. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage and isn't {@condition paralyzed}. At the end of each of its turns, a {@condition paralyzed} target can make another Wisdom saving throw. On a success, the condition ends on the target.

entries.name: Multiple Creatures
entries: Each creature in a 20-foot-radius sphere centered on a point you can see within 100 feet of you must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes {@damage 5d10} force damage and is knocked {@condition prone}. On a successful save, the creature takes half as much damage and isn't knocked {@condition prone}.

subclassFeature.name: Wyrdweaver
entries: Your patron is probability itself, the personified wellspring of chance as embodied by chosen deities, entities, and eldritch beings across the planes. By binding yourself to the Wyrdweaver, you live by the roll of the dice and the flip of the coin, delighting in the randomness of life and the thrill of new experiences. You might find yourself driven to invade a lich's keep to ask it about its favorite song, or you might leap onto a dragon's back to have the right to call yourself a dragonrider. Life with a pact-bond to your patron might not be long, but it will be exciting.

subclassFeature.name: Expanded Spell List
entries: The Wyrdweaver lets you choose from an expanded list of spells when you learn a warlock spell. The following spells are added to the warlock spell list for you.

entries.caption: Wyrdweaver Expanded Spells
rows: 1st
{@spell bane}, {@spell faerie fire}
2nd
{@spell blur}, {@spell frenzied bolt|ToH}*
3rd
{@spell bestow curse}, {@spell hypnotic pattern}
4th
{@spell compulsion}, {@spell reset|ToH}*
5th
{@spell battle mind|ToH}*, {@spell mislead}

subclassFeature.name: Probability Wellspring
entries: Starting at 1st level, you gain the ability to manipulate probability. You have a pool of {@damage d6}s that you spend to fuel your patron abilities. The number of probability dice in the pool equals 1 + your warlock level.

You can use these dice to turn the odds in your or your ally's favor. When you or a friendly creature you can see within 30 feet of you makes an attack roll, ability check, or saving throw, you can use your reaction to expend probability dice from the pool, rolling the dice and adding the total result to that roll. The maximum number of dice you can spend at once equals your Charisma modifier (minimum of one die). Your pool regains all expended dice when you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.
When you reach certain levels in this class, the size of your probability dice increases: at 5th level ({@damage d8}), 11th level ({@damage d10}), and 17th level ({@damage d12}).

subclassFeature.name: Appropriate Advantage
entries: At 1st level, you learn to shift the weaves of fate to aid allies and hinder foes. When a creature you can see within 60 feet of you makes an attack roll, ability check, or saving throw with advantage, you can use your reaction to expend one {@subclassFeature Probability Wellspring|Warlock|PHB|Wyrdweaver|ToH|1||probability die} and force that creature to make a Charisma saving throw against your spell save DC, adding the {@subclassFeature Probability Wellspring|Warlock|PHB|Wyrdweaver|ToH|1||probability die} to the DC. On a failed save, the creature loses advantage on that roll, and one friendly creature you can see within 60 feet has advantage on its next d20 roll of the same type the creature used (attack roll, ability check, or saving throw).

subclassFeature.name: Improbable Duplicate
entries: At 6th level, you can channel dark power from your patron to empower your attacks and spells. Once on each of your turns, when you hit a creature with an attack, you can expend one or more {@subclassFeature Probability Wellspring|Warlock|PHB|Wyrdweaver|ToH|1||probability dice}, up to half your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1), and add the {@subclassFeature Probability Wellspring|Warlock|PHB|Wyrdweaver|ToH|1||probability dice} to the attack's damage roll.

subclassFeature.name: Inconceivable Channeling
entries: At 10th level, you learn to redirect magical energy, converting the power to restore your pool of {@subclassFeature Probability Wellspring|Warlock|PHB|Wyrdweaver|ToH|1||probability dice}. When a friendly creature you can see within 30 feet of you takes acid, cold, fire, lightning, or thunder damage, you can use your reaction to take the damage instead. You halve the damage you take as your {@subclassFeature Probability Wellspring|Warlock|PHB|Wyrdweaver|ToH|1} absorbs some of the magical energy. For every 10 damage prevented in this way, you regain one expended {@subclassFeature Probability Wellspring|Warlock|PHB|Wyrdweaver|ToH|1||probability die}. You can't regain more than half your maximum {@subclassFeature Probability Wellspring|Warlock|PHB|Wyrdweaver|ToH|1||probability dice} from this feature. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Favored Soul
entries: Starting at 14th level, your very presence spins probability. When a creature you can see within 60 feet of you makes an attack roll, ability check, or saving throw with advantage, you can use your reaction to force the creature to make a Charisma saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, the creature has disadvantage on that roll, and you have advantage on one d20 roll of your choice within the next minute. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Cantrip Adept
entries: It's easy to dismiss the humble cantrip as nothing more than an unsophisticated spell practiced by hedge wizards that proper mages need not focus on. But clever and cautious wizards sometimes specialize in such spells because while other mages fret when they're depleted of arcane resources, Cantrip Adepts hardly even notice ... and at their command, the cantrips are not so humble.

subclassFeature.name: Cantrip Polymath
entries: At 2nd level, you gain {@filter two cantrips of your choice from any spell list|spells|source=|level=0}. For you, these cantrips count as wizard cantrips and don't count against the number of cantrips you know. In addition, any cantrip you learn or can cast from any other source, such as from a racial trait or feat, counts as a wizard cantrip for you.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Alacrity
entries: Also at 2nd level, whenever you cast a {@filter wizard cantrip that has a casting time of an action|spells|source=|level=0|cast time=action}, you can change the casting time to a bonus action for that casting. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses of it when you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.
When you reach 10th level in this class, you regain all expended uses of this feature when you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Potent Spellcasting
entries: Starting at 6th level, you can add your Intelligence modifier to one damage roll of any {@filter wizard cantrip|spells|source=|level=0} you can cast.

subclassFeature.name: Adroit Caster
entries: Starting at 10th level, if you cast a cantrip that doesn't deal damage or a cantrip that has an effect in addition to damage, such as the speed reduction of the {@spell ray of frost} spell, that cantrip or effect has twice the normal duration.

subclassFeature.name: Empowered Cantrips
entries: Starting at 14th level, once per turn, when you cast a wizard {@filter cantrip that deals damage|spells|source=|level=0|damage type=acid;bludgeoning;cold;fire;force;lightning;necrotic;piercing;poison;psychic;radiant;slashing;thunder}, you can deal maximum damage with that spell. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and you regain all expended uses of it when you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Courser Mage
entries: A tradition more focused on stalking prey than reading dozens of books, courser mages generally choose more subtle spells that aid in finding or hiding from their enemies. They learn to imbue their arrows with spell energy to deliver more deadly shots.

subclassFeature.name: Stalking Savant
entries: At 2nd level, you gain proficiency with {@item longbow|PHB|longbows} and {@item shortbow|PHB|shortbows}, and you gain proficiency in the {@skill Stealth} skill. In addition, you can still perform the somatic components of wizard spells even when you have a longbow or shortbow in one or both hands.

subclassFeature.name: Unseen Assailant
entries: Starting at 2nd level, as a bonus action, you can choose a target you can see within 60 feet of you and become {@condition invisible} to that target until the start of your next turn. Once the effect ends, you can't use this feature on that target again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Spell Arrow
entries: Beginning at 6th level, you can imbue an arrow you fire from a {@item longbow|PHB} or {@item shortbow|PHB} with magical energy. As a bonus action, you can expend a 1st-level spell slot to cause the next arrow you fire to magically deal an extra {@damage 2d4} force damage to the target on a hit. If you expend a spell slot of 2nd level or higher, the extra damage increases by {@damage 1d4} for each slot level above 1st.

subclassFeature.name: Pinpoint Weakness
entries: At 10th level, when you hit a creature with an arrow imbued by your {@subclassFeature Spell Arrow|Wizard|PHB|Courser Mage|ToH|6} feature, your next ranged weapon attack against that creature has advantage.

subclassFeature.name: Multitudinous Arrows
entries: Starting at 14th level, you can attack twice, instead of once, whenever you take the {@action Attack} action with a {@item longbow|PHB} or {@item shortbow|PHB} on your turn. If you use your {@subclassFeature Spell Arrow|Wizard|PHB|Courser Mage|ToH|6} feature, you can imbue both arrows witharcane power by expending one spell slot. If you imbue two arrows with this feature, you can't cast spells other than cantrips until the end of your next turn.

subclassFeature.name: Familiar Master
entries: Each wizard has a strong connection with their familiar, but some mages eschew specializing in a school of magic in favor of forming a powerful bond with a familiar. This bond allows the two to work in tandem in ways that few arcane practitioners could even dream of. Those who encounter such a familiar never look at a rodent or bird the same way again.

subclassFeature.name: Familiar Savant
entries: Beginning when you select this arcane tradition at 2nd level, you learn the {@spell find familiar} spell if you don't know it already. You innately know this spell and don't need to have it scribed in your spellbook or prepared in order to cast it. When you cast {@spell find familiar}, the casting time is 1 action, and it requires no material components.

You can cast {@spell find familiar} without expending a spell slot. You can do so a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|long rest}.

In addition, when you cast the {@spell find familiar} spell, you can choose for your familiar to take the form of {@filter any Small or smaller beast that is CR 1/4 or lower|bestiary|source=|Challenge Rating=[&0;&1/4]|type=beast|size=t;s}, such as a {@creature flying snake|MM}, {@creature giant moth|CCodex} (see Creature Codex), or {@creature giant armadillo|ToB2} (see Tome of Beasts 2). The familiar has the statistics of the chosen beast form, but it is a celestial, fey, or fiend (your choice) instead of a beast.

When you reach 6th level in this class, your familiar can take the form of {@filter any Small or smaller beast that is CR 1 or lower|bestiary|source=|Challenge Rating=[&0;&1]|type=beast|size=t;s}. Alternatively, at the GM's discretion, your familiar can be {@filter any Tiny celestial, dragon, fey, or fiend that is CR 1 or lower|bestiary|source=|Challenge Rating=[&0;&1]|type=celestial;dragon;fey;fiend|size=t;s}.

subclassFeature.name: Greater Familiar
entries: Also at 2nd level, when you cast {@spell find familiar}, your familiar gains the following additional benefits:

items: Your familiar adds your proficiency bonus to its Armor Class, and it uses your proficiency bonus in place of its own when making ability checks and saving throws. It is proficient in any saving throw in which you are proficient.

Your familiar's hit points equal its normal hit point maximum or 1 + your Intelligence modifier + three times your wizard level, whichever is higher. It has a number of Hit Dice ({@damage d4}s) equal to your wizard level.

In combat, your familiar shares your initiative and takes its turn immediately after yours. It can move and use its reaction on its own, but, if you don't issue any commands to it, the only action it takes is the {@action Dodge} action. You can use your bonus action to direct it to take any action in its stat block or some other action. If you are {@condition incapacitated}, the familiar can take any action of its choice, not just {@action Dodge}.

Your familiar's attacks are enhanced by the magic bond you share with it. When making attack rolls, your familiar uses your spell attack bonus or its normal attack bonus, whichever is higher. In addition, when your familiar hits with an attack, the attack deals force damage equal to {@damage 1d4} + its Strength or Dexterity modifier (your choice) + your proficiency bonus instead of its normal damage. If the familiar's attack normally deals additional damage, such as a flying snake's poison, or has an additional effect, such as an octopus's grapple, the familiar's attack still has that additional damage or effect.

Your familiar's Intelligence increases to 8 unless it is already higher. It can understand and speak {@language Common|PHB} and either {@language Celestial|PHB} (if celestial), {@language Sylvan|PHB} (if fey), or {@language Abyssal|PHB} or {@language Infernal|PHB} (if fiend).

subclassFeature.name: Strengthened Bond
entries: Starting at 6th level, your magical bond with your familiar grows stronger. If your familiar has a trait or action that forces a creature to make a saving throw, it uses your spell save DC. In addition, you can access your familiar's senses by using either an action or a bonus action, and whenever your familiar is within 100 feet of you, it can expend its reaction to deliver any {@filter wizard spell|spells|source=|class=wizard} you cast. If the spell has {@filter a range of 5 feet or more|spells|source=|class=wizard|range=!self;!touch}, you must be sharing your familiar's senses before casting the spell. If the spell requires an attack roll, ability check, or saving throw, you use your own statistics to adjudicate the result.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Amplification
entries: Starting at 10th level, you can add your Intelligence modifier to one damage roll of any {@filter wizard spell|spells|source=|class=wizard} you cast through your familiar. In addition, your familiar has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

subclassFeature.name: Companion Concentration
entries: Starting at 14th level, when you are {@filter concentrating on a spell of 3rd level or lower|spells|source=|level=1;2;3|components & miscellaneous=concentration}, you can use an action to draw on your connection with your familiar to pass the burden of {@condition concentration} onto it, freeing you up to concentrate on a different spell. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Gravebinding
entries: While most wizards who desire power over the dead focus their efforts on necromancy, there are other, rarer, paths one can choose. Gravebinders focus their efforts on safeguarding tombs and graveyards to ensure the dead remain at rest and the living remain safe from the dead. When undead rise to prey upon the living, a gravebinder hunts downs the abominations and returns them to their eternal slumber.

subclassFeature.name: Restriction: The Dead Must Rest
entries: When you choose this wizard arcane tradition, you can no longer cast spells that animate, conjure, or create undead, and, if any such spells are copied in your spellbook, they fade from the book within 24 hours, leaving blank pages where the spells were.

subclassFeature.name: Gravebinder Lore
entries: At 2nd level, you can use an action to inscribe a small rune on a corpse. While this rune remains, the corpse can't become undead. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (a minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.

In addition, you have proficiency in the {@skill Religion} skill if you don't already have it, and you have advantage on Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) checks made to recall lore about deities of death, burial practices, and the afterlife.

subclassFeature.name: Hunter of the Dead
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you gain access to spells passed down by generations of gravebinders. The {@spell heart to heart|ToH} (2nd), {@spell dead walking|ToH} (3rd), {@spell gird the spirit|ToH} (3rd), {@spell life from death|ToH} (5th), and {@spell lay to rest|ToH} (9th) spells are wizard spells for you, and you add them to your spellbook at the indicated wizard levels (see the Magic and Spells chapter for details on these spells). Once you gain access to one of these spells, you always have it prepared, and it doesn't count against the number of spells you can prepare each day.

Also at 2nd level, you can use your action and expend one wizard spell slot to focus your awareness on the region around you. For 1 minute per level of the spell slot you expend, you can sense whether undead are present within 1 mile of you. You know the general direction of the undead creatures, though not their exact locations or numbers, and you know the direction of the most powerful undead within range.

subclassFeature.name: Ward Against the Risen
entries: Starting at 6th level, when an undead creature you can see within 30 feet of you targets an ally with an attack or spell, you can use your reaction to hamper the attack or spell. The undead has disadvantage on its attack roll or your ally has advantage on its saving throw against the undead's spell. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your Intelligence modifier (a minimum of once). You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Disruptive Touch
entries: Beginning at 10th level, when an undead creature takes damage from a {@filter 1st-level or higher spell|spells|source=|level=1;2;3;4;5;6;7;8;9|class=wizard} you cast, it takes an extra {@damage 4d6} radiant damage. Undead creatures you kill using this feature are destroyed in a puff of golden motes.

subclassFeature.name: Radiant Nimbus
entries: At 14th level, you can use your action to envelope yourself in a shroud of golden flames for 1 minute. While enveloped, you gain the following benefits:

items: When you summon the flames and as an action on each of your turns while the flames are active, you can frighten undead within 30 feet of you. Each undead creature in the area must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition frightened} of you until the flames fade or until it takes damage. An undead creature with sunlight sensitivity (or hypersensitivity, in the case of vampires) also takes {@damage 4d6} radiant damage if it fails the saving throw.
You shed {@quickref Vision and Light|PHB|2|0|bright light} in a 30-foot radius and {@quickref Vision and Light|PHB|2|0|dim light} for an additional 30 feet. This light is sunlight.
When an undead creature hits you with a melee weapon attack, it takes {@damage 2d10} radiant damage.

entries: Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: School of Black Powder
entries: The school of black powder bridges magic and technology. Wizards of this school form a magical bond with a firearm, allowing them to channel their magic through the weapon to enhance its effects. Students go beyond simple offensive magics, using their black powder magic to great utility in aiding allies and hindering foes. Practitioners of this school refer to themselves as powdermancers, though manyfolk refer to all spellcasters with an affinity for firearms as "gun mages," not fully understanding firearms or the differences between the various magical disciplines and styles that utilize them.

subclassFeature.name: Gun Savant
entries: When you select this school at 2nd level, you gain proficiency with {@filter simple firearms|items|source=|type=simple weapon;firearm=sand} and with the {@item musket|ToH} (see the Adventuring Gear chapter for details on these weapons). When attacking with {@filter firearms|items|source=|type=firearm=sand}, you can use your Intelligence modifier, instead of Dexterity, for the attack and damage rolls. You can use a firearm as a spellcasting focus. In addition, you gain proficiency with {@item alchemist's supplies|PHB} or {@item gunsmith's tools|ToH} (your choice).

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Arms
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you can imbue your {@filter firearm|items|source=|type=firearm=sand} with arcane power to create minor magical effects. As an action, you can invoke one of the following effects, provided you have a {@filter gun|items|source=|type=firearm=sand} in your hand. The effects created by this feature don't cause the {@filter firearm|items|source=|type=firearm=sand} to release an audible boom, but other attacks or effects from your {@filter firearm|items|source=|type=firearm=sand} still create the sound. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.

entries.name: Arcane Dusting
entries: You shoot a 15-foot cone of magical dust from the barrel of your firearm. Each creature or object in the area that is currently being affected by a spell, such as {@spell mage armor}, or that is magical, such as {@item bracers of archery}, glows until the end of your next turn, shedding {@quickref Vision and Light|PHB|2|0|dim light} in a 5-foot radius.

entries.name: Flare
entries: You fire a bright ball of magical light from the barrel of your firearm. If fired into the air, the ball rises to a maximum height of 100 feet, unless stopped by an intervening obstacle, hovers until the end of your next turn, then falls slowly, reaching the ground by the end of the next round. The light extinguishes when it hits the ground. The flare can be seen up to 1 mile away in daylight or up to 5 miles in darkness. Alternatively, the flare can be fired up to 50 feet away in any other direction. Each creature within 5 feet of the path of the flare must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw against your spell save DC or have disadvantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight for 1 minute.

entries.name: Lockbuster
entries: You fire a magical shot from your firearm at a lock within the weapon's normal range. Make an attack roll with the firearm. If the result is equal to or exceeds the DC required to pick the lock, your shot destroys the lock. You have advantage on this attack roll if the lock is protected by magic, such as the {@spell arcane lock} spell.

entries.name: Smokescreen
entries: A cloud of smoke billows from your firearm, creating a 10-foot-radius sphere of smoke centered on you. The sphere spreads around corners, and its area is {@quickref Vision and Light|PHB|2|0|heavily obscured}. The cloud lasts until the end of your next turn or until a wind of moderate or greater speed (at least 10 miles per hour) disperses it. When you reach 6th level, the sphere's radius increases to 20 feet.

entries.name: Starter's Gun
entries: You discharge your firearm into the air. Each friendly creature of your choice within 30 feet of you has its speed increased by 10 feet until the start of your next turn. When you reach 10th level, each affected creature can also {@action Dash} as a bonus action on its turn.

entries.name: Tracer Shot
entries: You fire a ball of light at a creature you can see within 60 feet of you. Make a ranged attack with your firearm. On a hit, the attack deals damage as normal, and the target is outlined in light, as if affected by the {@spell faerie fire} spell, until the start of your next turn. When you reach 10th level, the target is outlined in light for 1 minute.

subclassFeature.name: Spell Shot
entries: Starting at 6th level, when you cast a spell that requires a melee spell attack roll, you can instead project the spell through your {@filter firearm|items|source=|type=firearm=sand}, using the {@filter firearm|items|source=|type=firearm=sand}'s normal range as the range of the spell. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|long rest}.
In addition, your attacks with a {@filter firearm|items|source=|type=firearm=sand} count as magical for the purpose of overcoming resistance and immunity to nonmagical attacks and damage.

subclassFeature.name: Improved Arcane Arms
entries: At 10th level, you are able to imbue your firearm with more powerful magical effects. When you use your {@subclassFeature Arcane Arms|Wizard|PHB|Black Powder|ToH|2} feature, you can choose one of the following effects instead. In addition, you can expend a spell slot of 2nd level or higher to regain a number of expended uses of your {@subclassFeature Arcane Arms|Wizard|PHB|Black Powder|ToH|2} feature equal to half the level of the spell slot.

entries.name: False Shot
entries: You fire an illusionary shot at a target within 30 feet, your weapon booming and smoking as if you had actually made an attack. The target must make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, the target is {@condition paralyzed} with fear until the start of your next turn. On a successful save, the target is {@condition frightened} of you until the start of your next turn.

entries.name: Invigorating Burst
entries: You discharge your firearm into the air, dispersing a magical dust that settles around you. Each creature of your choice within 20 feet of you, including yourself, gains {@damage 2d4} {@quickref temporary hit points|PHB|3|0} for 1 hour.

entries.name: Shot in the Arm
entries: As a bonus action, you can fire a crackling bolt of energy from your firearm at a friendly creature you can see within 60 feet of you. If the target is suffering from {@condition exhaustion}, its level of {@condition exhaustion} is reduced by 1. If not, the target gains 5 {@quickref temporary hit points|PHB|3|0} for 1 hour and has advantage on its next ability check, attack roll, or saving throw.

entries.name: Warning Shot
entries: You fire a shot into the air, producing a magically enhanced, thunderous boom. Each creature of your choice that you can see within 30 feet of you becomes indifferent about creatures of your choice that it is hostile toward. This indifference lasts for 1 minute. It ends early if an affected target isattacked, is harmed by a spell, witnesses any of its allies being harmed, or if you use your firearm to invoke another {@subclassFeature Arcane Arms|Wizard|PHB|Black Powder|ToH|2} effect before the duration ends.

subclassFeature.name: Hand Cannon
entries: At 14th level, when you make a ranged attack roll with a {@filter firearm|items|source=|type=firearm=sand}, you can expend a spell slot of 1st level or higher to imbue the {@filter firearm|items|source=|type=firearm=sand} with great arcane power. If you do, you gain a bonus on the attack roll equal to the spell's level. If you hit the target, the force of the shot continues in a 30-foot line that is 5 feet wide directly away from you and originating from the target. Each creature in that line must make a Dexterity saving throw against your spell save DC.

On a failed save, a creature takes {@damage 1d6} force damage for each slot level of the spell expended. On a successful save, a creature takes half as much damage. This damage can experience {@variantrule Gunpowder Burst|ToH|bursts}, as described in the gunpowder weapon property, but this effect counts as a single effect for the purposes of determining how many times the damage can {@variantrule Gunpowder Burst|ToH|burst}, regardless of the number of targets affected.

subclassFeature.name: School of Liminality
entries: Liminal spaces are spaces on the boundary, at the edge between what's real and what's unreal. A liminal space can be neither here nor there, and yet be both here and there at the same time. Stories of liminal spaces are common across cultures, though their true nature often isn't recognized by the uninitiated: the stranger who appears suddenly at a lonely crossroads, the troll that snatches at unwary travelers from a hiding spot beneath a bridge where no such hiding spot exists, the strangely familiar yet unsettlingly different scene that's sometimes glimpsed in a looking glass.

These are only the most obvious encounters with liminal spaces! Most liminalities are more easily overlooked, being as unconscious as the heartbeat between waking and sleeping, as fleeting as drawing in breath as an apprentice and exhaling it as a master, or as unassumingly familiar—and as fraught with potential—as a doorway that's crossed a hundred times without incident.

Those who specialize in liminal magic are known as liminists. They've learned to tap into the mysticism at the heart of spaces between spaces and to bend the possibilities inherent in transitional moments to their own ends. Like filaments of a dream, strands of liminality can be woven into forms new and wondrous—or strange and terrifying.

subclassFeature.name: Liminal Savant
entries: Beginning when you select this school at 2nd level, the gold and time you must spend to copy a {@filter liminal spell|spells|source=ToH|subschool=liminal} (see the Magic and Spells chapter) into your spellbook is halved.

subclassFeature.name: Mulligan
entries: At 2nd level, you can control the moment between an attempt at something and the result of that attempt to shift the flow of battle in your favor. When a creature you can see within 30 feet of you misses with an attack, you can use your reaction to allow that creature to reroll the attack. Similarly, when a creature within 30 feet of you that you can see hits with an attack but hasn't yet rolled damage, you can use your reaction to force that creature to reroll the attack and use the lower result. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|long rest}.
When you reach 10th level in this class, you can use this feature when a creature you can see within 30 feet of you makes an ability check or saving throw.

subclassFeature.name: Otherworldly Sense
entries: At 6th level, if you spend 1 minute meditating and expanding your senses outward, you can sense those not of this world — those who slip through the cracks of the in-between to wreak havoc on the unsuspecting. For 10 minutes, you can sense whether the following types of creatures are present within 1 mile of you: aberrations, celestials, dragons, elementals, fey, fiends, and undead. As long as you maintain your {@condition concentration}, you can use an action to change the type of creature you sense. You know the direction to each lone creature or group, but not the distance or the exact number in a group. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Liminal Adept
entries: At 10th level, you add the {@spell threshold slip} spell (see the Magic and Spells chapter) to your spellbook, if it isn't there already. You can cast {@spell threshold slip} without expending a spell slot. When you do so, you can bring up to two willing creatures of your size or smaller that you're touching with you. The target junction must have unoccupied spaces for all of you to enter when you reappear, or the spell fails.

You can use this feature twice. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}. When you reach 14th level in this class, you can use this feature three times between {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|rests}.

subclassFeature.name: Forced Transition
entries: At 14th level, your mastery over moments of change is unequivocal. You can use an action to touch a willing creature or make a melee spell attack against an unwilling creature, choosing one of the following effects. The effect lasts for 1 minute. Once you use this feature, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|long rest}.

entries.name: Rapid Advancement
entries: The target's ability scores are each increased by 2. An ability score can exceed 20 but can't exceed 24.

entries.name: Regression
entries: The target's ability scores are each reduced by 2. This effect can't reduce an ability score below 1.

entries.name: True Self
entries: The target can't change its shape through any means, including spells, such as {@spell polymorph}, and traits, such as the werewolf 's Shapechanger trait. The target immediately reverts to its true form if it is currently in a different form. This option has no effect on {@filter illusion spells|spells|source=|school=i}, such as {@spell disguise self}, or a creature that appears changed from the effects of an illusion, such as a hag's Illusory Appearance.

subclassFeature.name: Spellsmith
entries: Some wizards pride themselves on being spell artisans, carefully sculpting the magical energy of spells like smiths sculpt iron. Focusing on the artistry inherent in spellcasting, these wizards learn to tap the magical energy of spells and manipulate that energy to amplify or modify spells like no other arcane practitioners.

subclassFeature.name: Arcane Emendation
entries: Beginning when you choose this tradition at 2nd level, you can manipulate the magical energy in scrolls to change the spells written on them. While holding a scroll, you can spend 1 hour for each level of the spell focusing on the magic within the scroll to change the spell on the scroll to another spell. The new spell must be of the same school, must be on the wizard spell list, and must be of the same or lower level than the original spell. If the new spell has any material components with a cost, you must provide those when changing the scroll's original spell to the new spell, and the components are consumed as the new spell's magic overwrites the original spell on the scroll.

subclassFeature.name: Spell Transformation
entries: At 2nd level, you learn to mold the latent magical energy of your spells to cast new spells. While {@filter concentrating on a wizard spell|spells|source=|class=wizard|components & miscellaneous=concentration} that you cast using a spell slot, you can use an action to end your {@condition concentration} on that spell and use the energy to cast another wizard spell you have prepared without expending a spell slot. The new spell must be half the level (minimum of 1st) of the spell on which you were concentrating, and {@filter the new spell's casting time must be 1 action|spells|source=|level=!0|class=wizard|cast time=action}.
You can use this feature a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Spell Honing
entries: At 6th level, you can hold onto the magic of lasting spells or siphon off some of their magic to amplify spells you cast. If your {@condition concentration} is broken (willingly or unwillingly), the spell's magic lingers, causing the spell's effects to remain until the end of your next turn.

In addition, while concentrating on a {@filter spell with a duration of concentration up to 1 minute or concentration up to 10 minutes|spells|source=|class=wizard|components & miscellaneous=concentration|Duration=[&Instant;&10 Minutes]}, you can amplify a {@filter wizard spell you cast of 1st level or higher|spells|source=|level=!0|class=wizard}. When you amplify a spell in this way, the duration of the spell on which you are concentrating is reduced by a number of rounds (if the duration is concentration up to 1 minute) or minutes (if the duration is concentration up to 10 minutes) equal to the amplified spell's level. You can choose only one of the following options when amplifying a spell:

items: Increase the saving throw DC by 2
Increase the spell attack bonus by 2
Add your Intelligence modifier to one damage roll of the spell.

entries: You can amplify a spell this way a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus. You regain all expended uses when you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|long rest}.

subclassFeature.name: Spell Reversion
entries: At 10th level, you learn to manipulate the magical energy of spells cast against you. When you must make a saving throw to end an ongoing effect, such as the {@condition frightened} condition of the fear spell or the slowing effect of a copper dragon's slowing breath, you have advantage on the saving throw.

In addition, when an ongoing condition you successfully end on yourself was from a spell cast by a creature you can see, you can use your reaction to force that creature to make the same saving throw against your spell save DC. On a failed save, the creature suffers the effect or condition you just ended on yourself until the end of its next turn. For example, if you succeed on the saving throw to end the {@condition paralyzed} condition on yourself from the {@spell hold person} spell cast by a spellcaster you can see, you can force that spellcaster to make a Wisdom saving throw against your spell save DC, and that spellcaster becomes {@condition paralyzed} until the end of its next turn on a failed save.

subclassFeature.name: Spell Duality
entries: At 14th level, you become a master at manipulating and extending the magical energy of your long-lasting spells. You can {@condition concentration|PHB|concentrate} on two spells simultaneously. If you cast a third spell that requires {@condition concentration}, you lose {@condition concentration} on the oldest spell. When you take damage while concentrating on a spell and must make a Constitution saving throw to maintain {@condition concentration}, you make one saving throw for each source of damage, as normal. You don't have to make one saving throw for each spell you are maintaining. If you are concentrating on two spells and fail a Constitution saving throw to maintain {@condition concentration} because of taking damage, you lose {@condition concentration} on the oldest spell.
If you are concentrating on two spells and lose {@condition concentration} on both spells in 1 round, you suffer one level of {@condition exhaustion}.

optionalfeature.name: Gunfighting
entries: When you roll a 1 on a damage die for an attack you make with a weapon with the gunpowder property, you can reroll the die and must use the new roll, even if the new roll is a 1. The weapon must have the gunpowder property for you to gain this benefit.

optionalfeature.name: Autonomous Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that has a duration of {@filter concentration|spells|source=|components=concentration}, you can spend 3 sorcery points to cast it without requiring {@condition concentration}. For example, using autonomous spell on {@spell detect magic} changes its duration to 10 minutes. You can have only one autonomous spell in effect at a time. If you use this metamagic to modify a second spell, the first autonomous spell ends.

optionalfeature.name: Bewildering Spell
entries: You can cast a spell that overwhelms the senses of its target. When you cast a spell that deals damage to one creature, you can spend 2 sorcery points to increase the intensity of the spell's visual effect. The target of your spell has disadvantage on the next Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma saving throw it makes within the next minute.

optionalfeature.name: Concussive Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that deals damage to a creature, you can spend 1 sorcery point to push the target of your spell 10 feet away from you. If the spell affects multiple targets, you can choose only one of the targets to be pushed away from you.

optionalfeature.name: Contingent Spell
entries: You can cast a spell to be triggered at a later time. To do so, you must spend a number of sorcery points equal to the level of the spell slot used to cast the spell. You then use your reaction to trigger the spell when the event you stipulated when you cast the spell occurs.

For example, you use your action, expend a 4th-level spell slot, and spend 4 sorcery points to cast {@spell dimension door} as a contingent spell that will take effect when a creature moves within 5 feet of you. When a creature moves within 5 feet of you a moment later, you use your reaction to trigger the {@spell dimension door} and teleport to a space 200 feet away.

optionalfeature.name: Emotional Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that allows its target to make a Wisdom saving throw, you can spend 3 sorcery points to change the type of saving throw required to a Charisma saving throw instead.

optionalfeature.name: Enlightening Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that targets a creature, you can spend 1 sorcery point to learn one of your target's resistances or immunities. Each time you use this metamagic option on the same creature, it reveals a new resistance or immunity.

optionalfeature.name: Fearful Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that deals damage to a creature, you can spend 3 sorcery points to make the target of your spell {@condition frightened} of you until the end of your next turn. If your spell affects multiple targets, you can choose only one of the targets to be {@condition frightened}.

optionalfeature.name: Hidden Spell
entries: When you cast a spell with a duration longer than instantaneous, you can spend 2 sorcery points to mask its magical aura. For the duration of your spell, it can't be detected or discerned with spells or effects, such as the {@spell detect magic} spell or a chuul's Sense Magic trait.

optionalfeature.name: Homing Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that deals damage to one creature, you can spend 2 sorcery points to target a creature that has {@quickref Cover|PHB|3|0|total cover} or is {@quickref Vision and Light|PHB|2|0|heavily obscured}, provided you are aware of the target's presence. This metamagic option allows you to target the creature, but it doesn't cause the spell to automatically affect the target. As normal, the target must still make a saving throw or be hit by your spell attack to be affected by the spell.

optionalfeature.name: Hungry Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that deals damage to a single target, you can spend 1 sorcery point to add your Charisma modifier to the damage roll of the spell. If you reduce a creature to 0 hit points with a hungry spell, you regain hit points equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1).

optionalfeature.name: Immaterial Spell
entries: You can cast a spell without providing costly material components. You must spend 1 sorcery point for every 100 gp in the cost of the material component required.

optionalfeature.name: Insatiable Spell
entries: When you cast a spell on a creature that is immune to the damage or effects of the spell, you can spend 5 sorcery points to bypass the creature's immunity for this casting of the spell. The creature is affected by the spell as if it didn't have immunity to the spell's damage or effects and must make any saving throws allowed by the spell as normal.

optionalfeature.name: Lingering Spell
entries: When you cast a damaging spell with an instantaneous duration that requires a saving throw, you can spend a number of sorcery points equal to the spell's level to prolong the spell's damage. A creature that failed its saving throw against your original casting of this spell must succeed on the same saving throw at the start of your next turn or take half of the spell's damage.

optionalfeature.name: Logical Spell
entries: When you cast a spell that allows its target to make a Wisdom saving throw, you can spend 3 sorcery points to change the type of saving throw required to an Intelligence saving throw instead.

optionalfeature.name: Robust Spell
entries: You can make a spell difficult for other spellcasters to counter or dispel by spending 2 sorcery points. A creature that must make an ability check to counter or dispel your spell has disadvantage on the check.

optionalfeature.name: Sapping Spell
entries: You can increase the damage you deal with a spell by expending 2 sorcery points and up to half your remaining Hit Dice. Roll the Hit Dice and add the total result to the damage dealt by the spell. You then take damage equal to half the amount of damage your Hit Dice added to the spell's damage.

optionalfeature.name: Shared Hunger Spell
entries: When you cast a beneficial spell on a friendly creature, you can spend 3 sorcery points to empower the creature's weapons. The creature's next weapon attack roll has advantage and, if the creature hits, you and the creature regain hit points equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum of 1).

optionalfeature.name: Chaotic Aegis
entries: The pact with your patron offers protection from the powers of entropy. When you or a creature targeting you with an effect must roll a die or dice and consult a table to determine the outcome of the effect, such as with the {@spell confusion} spell, you can use your reaction to force a reroll of the die or dice. You must use the new result. You must finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest} before you can use this invocation again.

optionalfeature.name: Chaotic Luck
entries: The tumbling dice of fate sometimes fall in your favor. When you are hit by an attack, you can use your reaction to force the attacker to reroll the damage dice. You must accept the new damage roll. You must finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest} before you can use this invocation again.

optionalfeature.name: Convulsions of the World
entries: Your mind reaches deep into the ground and an elder voice answers. You can use an action to cause a localized tremor to shake the ground around you. Each creature other than yourself within 20 feet of you must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or be knocked {@condition prone}. You can choose a number of creatures equal to half your proficiency bonus to automatically succeed on this saving throw. You must finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest} before you can use this invocation again.

optionalfeature.name: Doom Hound
entries: As a bonus action, your familiar transforms into a more powerful creature for 1 minute. At 7th level and higher, it transforms into a {@creature dire wolf|MM}. At 12th level and higher, it transforms into a {@creature winter wolf|MM}. At 18th level and higher, it transforms into a hound of the night (see Tome of Beasts). You must finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest} before you can use this invocation on your familiar again.

optionalfeature.name: Earthblood Geyser
entries: Tapping the living mind of the world, you call forth retribution from the ground. You can cast {@spell magma spray|ToH} (see the Magic and Spells chapter) at will, without expending a spell slot or material components.

optionalfeature.name: Echo of the First Words
entries: The echo of the first magical utterance reverberates across time, confounding those who hear it. You can cast {@spell babble|ToH} once using a warlock spell slot. You can't do so again until you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

optionalfeature.name: Entangling Blast
entries: When you hit a creature with {@spell eldritch blast}, the creature must succeed on a Dexterity saving throw or be {@condition grappled} by roots, vines, and other vegetation until the end of its next turn. The DC for this saving throw and to escape this {@action grapple} is your spell save DC.

optionalfeature.name: Extinguishing Blast
entries: When you hit a creature with {@spell eldritch blast}, you reduce the light surrounding it until the end of your next turn. If the creature is in {@quickref Vision and Light|PHB|2|0|bright light}, the area within 10 feet of it becomes {@quickref Vision and Light|PHB|2|0|dim light}. If the creature is in {@quickref Vision and Light|PHB|2|0|dim light}, the area within 10 feet of it becomes {@quickref Vision and Light|PHB|2|0|darkness}.

optionalfeature.name: Forest-Trained
entries: You gain proficiency in the {@skill Nature} and {@skill Survival} skills.

optionalfeature.name: Green Thumb
entries: You can cast {@spell plant growth} once using a warlock spell slot. You can't do so again until you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

optionalfeature.name: Improved Companion
entries: When your patron sends you a beast as part of your {@subclassFeature Patron Companion|Warlock|PHB|Animal Lords|ToH|6} feature, you can choose a beast that relates to your patron (as shown in the beast type column in the Animal Lords table) that has a {@filter challenge rating of 3 or lower|bestiary|Challenge Rating=[&0;&3]|type=beast}.

optionalfeature.name: Knowledge of the Wood
entries: When you are within 5 feet of a body of water in a forest, you can cast {@spell scrying} on any creature in that forest at will, without expending a warlock spell slot or material components. You must remain within 5 feet of the body of water for the duration or the spell ends.

optionalfeature.name: Lurker in Gloom
entries: As a reaction when you take damage while in {@quickref Vision and Light|PHB|2|0|dim light or darkness}, you wrap shadows around yourself and have resistance to that instance of damage. Once you use this invocation, you can't use it again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.

optionalfeature.name: Patient Hunter
entries: When you identify a creature's tracks using your tome, you have advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) and Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) checks to find and track the creature for the next 24 hours.

optionalfeature.name: Primal Link
entries: You can cast {@spell animal friendship} at will, without expending a spell slot or material components.

optionalfeature.name: Shadow Arrow
entries: When you hit a creature with an arrow shot from your pact weapon, you can fire a second, shadow arrow at the creature as a bonus action. If it hits, the shadow arrow deals necrotic damage equal to the damage dealt by the first arrow.

optionalfeature.name: Silent Stalker
entries: You gain proficiency in the {@skill Stealth} and {@skill Survival} skills.

optionalfeature.name: Speaker for the Trees
entries: You can cast {@spell speak with plants} at will without expending a spell slot.

optionalfeature.name: Touch of the Forest
entries: You can cast {@spell awaken} once using a warlock spell slot. You can't do so again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.

optionalfeature.name: Acidum
entries: {@i The rune of undoing}
{@bold Type}: Damage Rune
{@bold Representation}: Acid

{@bold Spellcasting Focus}: When you use {@i acidum} as a spellcasting focus while casting a {@filter spell that deals damage that isn't acid|spells|source=|damage type=!acid;bludgeoning;cold;fire;force;lightning;necrotic;piercing;poison;psychic;radiant;slashing;thunder}, change the spell's damage type to acid. Once used to change the damage type of three spells, {@i acidum} can't be used this way again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.

optionalfeature.name: Acies
entries: {@i The rune of pathways}
{@bold Type}: Area Rune

{@bold Spellcasting Focus}: When you use {@i acies} as a spellcasting focus while casting a {@filter spell that affects a line|spells|source=|area style=l}, you can modify the size of the line. You can increase the line's length by 10 feet or its width by 5 feet.

Once used to change the damage type of three spells, {@i cerebrum} can't be used this way again until you finish a {@quickref resting|phb|2|0|long rest}.

For example, a spell that lasts 1 round lasts 2 rounds when you use this rune as a spellcasting focus. If the {@filter spell requires concentration|spells|source=|components & miscellaneous=concentration|Duration=[&Instant;&1 Minute]}, you must still maintain {@i concentration}.

items.name: Tool Proficiencies:
items.entry: One type of {@filter artisan's tools|items|source=phb|miscellaneous=mundane|type=artisan's tools} set of your choice

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: A set of {@filter artisan's tools|items|source=phb|miscellaneous=mundane|type=artisan's tools} of your choice, a unique piece of jewelry, a set of {@item fine clothes|PHB}, a handcrafted pipe, and a belt {@item pouch|PHB} containing 20 gp

entries.name: Feature: Servant's Invisibility
entries: The art of excellent service requires a balance struck between being always available and yet unobtrusive, and you've mastered it. If you don't perform a visible action, speak or be spoken to, or otherwise have attention drawn to you for at least 1 minute, creatures nearby have trouble remembering you are even in the room. Until you speak, perform a visible action, or have someone draw attention to you, your proficiency bonus) to notice you. Otherwise, they conduct themselves as though you aren't present until either attention is drawn to you or one of their actions would take them into or within 5 feet of the space you occupy.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Court servants tend to be outwardly quiet and soft-spoken, but their insight into the nuances of conversation and societal happenings is unparalleled. When in crowds or around strangers, most court servants keep to themselves, quietly observing their surroundings and later sharing such observations with those they trust.

rows: Unless I must speak, I hold my breath while serving others.
It takes all my effort not to show the effusive emotions I feel when I help others. Best to quietly serve.
It's getting harder to tolerate the prejudices of those I serve daily.
Though the old ways are hard to give up, I want to be my own boss. I'll decide my path.
Serving my family and friends is the only thing I truly care about.
City life is killing my soul. I long for the old courtly ways.
It's time for my fellows to wake up and be taken advantage of no longer.
It's the small things that make it all worthwhile. I try to be present in every moment.
{@bold Family.} My family, whether the one I come from or the one I make, is the thing in this  most worth protecting. (Any)
{@bold Service.} I am most rewarded when I know I have performed a valuable service for another. (Good)
{@bold Sloth.} What's the point of helping anyone now that I've been discarded? (Chaotic)
{@bold Compassion.} I can't resist helping anyone in need. (Good)
{@bold Tradition.} Life under my master's rule was best, and things should be kept as close to their ideals as possible. (Lawful)
{@bold Joy.} The pursuit of happiness is the only thing worth serving anymore. (Neutral)
My family needs me to provide for them. They mean everything to me, which means I'll do whatever it takes.
My kin have served this holding and its lords and ladies for generations. I serve them faithfully to make my lineage proud.
I can't read the inscriptions on this odd ring, but it's all I have left of my family and our history of loyal service.
I'm with the best friends a person can ask for, so why do I feel so lonesome and homesick?
I've found a profession where my skills are put to good use, and I won't let anyone bring me down.
I found peace in a special garden filled with beautiful life, but I only have this flower to remind me. Someday I'll remember where to find that garden.
I would rather serve darkness than serve no one.
I'm afraid of taking risks that might be good for me.
I believe my master's people are superior to all others, and I'm not afraid to share that truth.
I always do as I'm told, even though sometimes I don't think I should.
I know what's best for everyone, and they'd all be better off if they'd follow my advice.
I can't stand seeing ugly or depressing things. I'd much rather think happy thoughts.

entries: Even though you are independent now, you were once a servant to a merchant, noble, regent, or other person of high station. You are an expert in complex social dynamics and knowledgeable in the history and customs of courtly life. Work with your GM to determine whom you served and why you are no longer a servant: did your master or masters retire and no longer require servants, did you resign from the service of a harsh master, did the court you served fall to a neighboring empire, or did something else happen?

items.name: Equipment:
items.entry: {@item Traveler's clothes|PHB}, {@item herbalism kit|PHB}, {@item waterskin|PHB}, {@item pouch|PHB} with 10 gp

entries.name: Feature: Nomad
entries: Living in the open desert has allowed your body to adapt to a range of environmental conditions. You can survive on 1 gallon of water in hot conditions (or 12 gallon in normal conditions) without being forced to make Constitution saving throws, and you are considered naturally adapted to hot climates. While in a desert, you can read the environment to predict natural weather patterns and temperatures for the next 24 hours, allowing you to cross dangerous terrain at the best times. The accuracy of your predictions is up to the GM, but they should be reliable unless affected by magic or unforeseeable events, such as distant earthquakes or volcanic eruptions.

entries.name: Suggested Characteristics
entries: Those raised in the desert can be the friendliest of humanoids—knowing allies are better than enemies in that harsh environment—or territorial and warlike, believing that protecting food and water sources by force is the only way to survive.

rows: I'm much happier sleeping under the stars than in a bed in a stuffy caravanserai.
It's always best to help a traveler in need; one day it might be you.
I am slow to trust strangers, but I'm extremely loyal to my friends.
If there's a camel race, I'm the first to saddle up!
I always have a tale or poem to share at the campfire.
I don't like sleeping in the same place more than two nights in a row.
I've been troubled by dreams for the last month. I am determined to uncover their meaning.
I feel lonelier in a crowded city than I do out on the empty desert sands.
{@bold Greater Good.} The needs of the whole tribe outweigh those of the individuals who are part of it. (Good)
{@bold Nature.} I must do what I can to protect the beautiful wilderness from those who would do it harm. (Neutral)
{@bold Tradition.}  I am duty-bound to follow my tribe's age-old route through the desert. (Lawful)
{@bold Change.} Things seldom stay the same and we must always be prepared to go with the flow. (Chaotic)
{@bold Honor.} If I behave dishonorably, my actions will bring shame upon the entire tribe. (Lawful)
